v.desc:
This program simulates the changes in liquid surface and pressure at the two pistons when the area ratio and forces applied to the two pistons change in an enclosed U-shaped container. The cross-sectional area of the piston on the left side is A1 and the cross-sectional area of the piston on the right side is A2. We define the area ratio of two pistons as Aratio = A2/A1. A2 is set to be a fixed value in the simulation. Users can adjust Aratio to change the value of A1. To make it easier to observe the relation between area ratio and forces applied to the two pistons, the weights of both pistons are assumed to be zero. When there are no objects on both pistons, the liquid surfaces below two pistons balance to the same level. Users can drag the weight and the elephant onto the pistons or change the weight of these two objects to observe the variations of liquid surface and pressure at the two pistons.

Alterable variables:
Mw: weight of standard weight (kgw)
Me: weight of elephant (kgw)
Aratio: area ration (A2/A1)

Checkbox: pressure. Click to show the pressure exerted on the piston.

Instructions:
(1) Drag the weight or the elephant and drop it on the piston.
(2) Adjust the value of Mw, Me, Aratio and observe the changes in levels of the liquid and pressure.
(3) Press “Reset” to restart the simulation.

This program simulates pressure variations in liquids when the surface of liquid in the container changes
v.desc:
This program simulates pressure variations in liquids when the surface of liquid in the container changes. In the simulation, there are two containers connected at the bottom via a tube and filled with liquids of density Da (g/cm3) and Db (g/cm3) respectively. A brown valve can be opened and closed to control the flow between the two containers. Two faucets (placed on the top-left and top-right) are used to add liquid to the containers. For pressure measurement, users can drag pressure gauges (4 gauges) to positions of interest in the containers. In this simulation, users can adjust the density of liquid, add liquid, and open/close the valve to explore how those factors or actions influence the pressure measured in a given position in the containers and how to calculate the liquid pressure.

Alterable variables:
Da: density of liquid A (g/cm3)
Db: density of liquid B (g/cm3)

Button:

Click the button to add liquid from each faucet in the condition when the valve is closed. The liquid will flow into the container from the faucet for two seconds with each click only if the container is not full.

‘add liquid A’: press this button to add liquid A

‘add liquid B’: press this button to add liquid B

Two-state button: ’open valve / close valve’: press the button to switch the state of the valve. If you would like to add liquid into containers, you have to set the button to the “close valve” state.

Checkbox ’measuring points’: Click it to show the assigned measuring points at the bottom of the two containers. Teachers could assign students to measure pressure at those points and check students’ answers in class or on the worksheet. Uncheck this box to hide the measuring points.

Instructions:
(1) Set variables (density of liquid), buttons of “add liquid” or “open/close valve”, and checkboxes; you can explore how those factors or actions influence the pressure measured at a given position within the liquid and how to calculate liquid pressure by dragging the pressure gauges to the desired position in the containers.
(2) To end the simulation and reset variables, please click “Reset”.

v.abstract: This simulation models motions of two spherical bodies while they orbit their collective center of mass due solely to the gravitational attraction between them.
v.desc:
This simulation models two spherical bodies attracted by universal gravitation (and no external force) orbiting their collective center of mass. Assume that the distance d between the two bodies is fixed and that both bodies undergo uniform circular motion. The mass of sphere A is Ma, and the mass of sphere B is Mratio times of that of A. The gravitational force between the two bodies is F=G∗Ma∗Mb/d2 
The two bodies will orbit with radius Ra (distance from sphere A to the system's center of mass) and radius Rb (distance from sphere B to the system’s center of mass) around their collective center of mass, respectively. d = |Ra| + |Rb|﻿

When Mratio = 1, the two bodies are equal in mass, and the center of mass of the system is at d/2. The radii of the orbits of the 2 bodies are the same, and the magnitudes of the angular velocities, linear velocities, and periods of the 2 bodies are also the same. However, the directions of their motions are opposite. Can you explain why?
When sphere B increases in mass, the center of mass of the system moves closer to B, and the radius of B’s orbit becomes smaller. As the 2 bodies orbit around their center of mass, can you figure out the ratios of their orbital radii, angular velocities, periods, linear velocities, linear momentums, and angular momentums?
The ratio of the masses of Earth to the moon is 80. Set Mratio = 80 and observe. 

Alterable Variables:
Mratio: ratio of the masses of the 2 bodies (Mb/Ma) (Note: Ma is a fixed value, and changing Mratio will change the value of Mb)
Show vectors: check to show force vectors
Instructions:
Set Mratio to desired value and click Play to run simulation. Click Pause/Play to pause and resume simulation. Click Reset to end

simulation.References: http://www.phy.ntnu.edu.tw/ntnujava/index.php?topic=2184 (NTNU Professor Fu-Kwun Huang’s Virtual Physics Laboratory)

v.abstract: This simulation explores the configuration of an electric field with multiple point charges.
v.desc:
This simulation explores the configuration of an electric field with multiple point charges. At the bottom left corner of the simulation screen, there are positive point charges, negative point charges, and electric field intensity sensors (4 each). Students can drag them onto the simulation screen. Gray arrows in the simulation screen represent the electric field. The length and direction of a sensor’s arrow represent the direction and strength/intensity of the electric field at that position.

Instructions:

(1)   Design the distribution of point charges and observe the resulting electric field.
(2)   Using the electric field intensity sensors, explore the differences in intensity and direction at various positions in the electric field. The closer a sensor is to a point charge, the greater the intensity (and the longer the arrow).
Click Reset to end or restart simulation.

v.desc:
This program simulates the process of a shooter operating a slingshot as he firstly pulls the rubber band and then releases a projectile. In the simulation, users can choose the mode of operating the slingshot and types of rubber band. The objective of the simulation is to make the projectile hit the angry bird when it lands on the ground. As the shooter pulls the rubber band, the force does work to the rubber band, storing energy in the form of elastic potential energy in the rubber band. As the rubber band is released, the elastic potential energy is converted into the kinetic energy of the projectile. The projectile gains velocity and shoots out. To hit the target, what combination of mode of operating the slingshot and type of rubber band should you choose? How do those factors affect the motion of the projectile?

Modes of operating the slingshot:
“Fixed maximum force” mode: The projectiles will be released when the force reaches the maximum magnitude of 20N.
“Fixed displacement” mode: The projectiles will be released when the displacement of the rubber band reaches a value of 0.4m(40cm)

Types of rubber band:
Two in series: Two identical rubber bands in series are attached to the slingshot. The elastic constant of each band is 50N/m
One: One rubber band is attached to the slingshot. Its elastic constant is 50N/m
Two in parallel: Two identical rubber bands in parallel are attached to the slingshot. The elastic constant of each band is 50N/m

Checkboxes:
"Pause at fixed points when pulling the bow”: For easier observation, the simulation pauses automatically every time the string of the bow is pulled back by 0.1 m. To continue the simulation, press the “Play” button.
"data”: Click to show the data for observation.
"graph”: Click to show the graph of force vs. displacement. Click on the graph to show the area of F-S.

Instruction:
(1) Set operating mode and rubber band type.
(2) Click “Play” to start the simulation.
(3) Click “Reset” to end the simulation

v.desc:
This program simulates the motion and trajectory of a binary star system. The user can set the orbit of the binary star to be a circle or ellipse, and the mass ratio (Mratio) of the binary star. Observe the changes in the trajectory, orbit radius, period, angular velocity, velocity, force, etc. of the two stars by adjusting the mass ratio of the two stars. The user can also use the data provided in the data table to further calculate the relationship between the velocity of the center of mass, the momentum ratio of the two stars, angular momentum ratio, etc.
Simulation instructions:
Orbit option:
Perfect circle: The orbits of the two stars are perfect circles.
Ellipse: The orbits of the two stars are elliptical.

Alterable parameters:
Mratio: the mass ratio between the two stars (Mb/Ma)
Checkboxes:
Center of mass: select to display the center of mass of the system (Pink dots)
Orbit radius: Click to show the orbit radius of the two stars; the dark green straight line represents the orbit radius of the A star. The dark blue straight line represents the orbit radius of star B.
angular velocity: Click to show the angular velocity of the two stars; the dark green arrow represents the angular velocity of star A. And the blue arrow represents the angular velocity of star B.
Free-body diagram: Click to show the forces acting on the two stars; the gray arrow represents the gravity acting on star A, and the orange arrow represents the gravity acting on star B.

v.desc:
This is a simulation of two types of linear motion: constant velocity and constant acceleration. Bicycle: constant velocity. Car: constant acceleration. At the starting point x = 0, the bicycle is on a rack so that the cycler could keep the wheels spinning at a certain, constant velocity Vb m/s, and the car has an initial velocity of 0 m/s. When the simulation starts, the bicycle will travel at constant velocity Vb while the car will undergo an acceleration of a m/s^2. The length of the track is 150 m.

(1) Both the bicycle's velocity and the car’s acceleration can be changed. (2) The goal is to make the bicycle and the car arrive at the red finish line (x = 150) at the same time. Notes: At the moment the bicycle passes the finish line, if the distance between the car and the bicycle is less than 2 meters, the objective is considered completed.

v.ml_infoTitle: Friction: How Far Can It Slide
v.desc:
A skater skates from ice (no friction) onto grass (friction present), where he eventually stops. In the simulation a person with mass M (kg) slides at velocity V0 (m/s) on ice (assume no friction between skates and ice) and moves onto grass. The coefficient of friction between the skates and the grass is μs. Frictional force between the skates and the grass causes the skater to slow down and eventually stop moving. The skater’s kinetic energy is decreased by the negative work of friction. How far can the skater slide until he stops completely? What factors affect this distance? (For simplicity, assume gravitational acceleration g = 10 m/s2.)

Alterable Variables:
V0: initial velocity of the skater (m/s)
μs: coefficient of friction between skates and grass
M: skater’s mass (kg)

Instructions:
Set variables to desired values and click Play to begin simulation. Click Reset to end simulation.

v.ml_infoTitle: Thin convex lens set – microscopes and telescopes
v.desc:
This program simulates the imaging ray diagrams of magnifying glasses, microscopes, and telescopes. The user can choose to observe the dynamic ray diagrams of magnifying lens, microscope, and telescope.

Magnifying lens: Place the upright object at the left of the thin convex lens within one focal distance. The light scattered off the object gets refracted by the convex lens and forms an upright enlarged virtual image.

Microscope: A microscope consists of two pieces of thin convex lenses. The specimen placed before the focal point of the object lens is transformed into an enlarged virtual image by the refraction of the lens set. The object lens, which is closer to the specimen, is a convex lens with a shorter focal length. The specimen is placed at the left of the lens near the focal point. The specimen forms an enlarged inverted real image on its right side by the object lens. The image is close to the focal point of the eyepiece. The eyepiece acts as and magnifying lens to convert the real image to an enlarged inverted virtual image by refraction. 

Telescope: The Keplerian telescope utilizes a combination of two thin convex lenses. The subject of observation standing upright in the distance gets refracted by the lens set and becomes an inverted virtual image. The object lens, closer to the subject of observation, is a convex lens that has a longer focal length than the eyepiece. The observation object located at a distance is refracted by the object lens and becomes an inverted and reduced real image. The imaging position falls on the focus of the objective lens at the right side and is within the focal distance of the eyepiece; the eyepiece acts as a magnifying glass, and this inverted real image is then refracted by the eyepiece and becomes enlarged inverted virtual image.

 

Alterable parameters：

Modes: "Magnifying glass"; "Microscope"; "Telescope"
Checkboxes：
Ray diagram: Click to display the dynamic optical diagram

Simulation instruction：
Click to select the mode or checkboxes
v.abstract: This program simulates the imaging optical path of magnifying glasses, microscopes, and telescopes.

v.desc:
This simulation models a system in which both momentum and mechanical energy are conserved. Two balls are dropped with initial velocity of zero. When the two balls are dropped side by side from the same height, they will bounce up to the same initial height after hitting the ground because no mechanical energy is lost. When the two balls are dropped in a stacked position and the blue ball A (mass Ma) collides, after bouncing off the ground, with red ball B (mass Mb), it will be a perfectly elastic collision. Observe how the behaviors of the two balls change with the ratio of their masses Ma/Mb. Can you explain the rebound height of the red ball using concepts of the conservation of momentum during perfectly elastic collisions and the conservation of mechanical energy? (The long rectangular box on the right displays the balls at ⅓ of their original scale.)

Modes:

Side-by-Side: The balls are held at the same height, side by side, and dropped with initial velocity 0.

Stacked: The red ball B is placed on top of the blue ball A, and the two balls are dropped in this formation with initial velocity 0.

Alterable Variables:

ratio: ratio of the masses of the 2 balls (Ma/Mb)

h: distance from the blue ball to the floor

Instructions:

(1) Choose a mode: “Side-by-Side” of “Stacked”

(2) Set variables (ratio, h) to desired values and click Play to run simulation. Click Reset to end simulation.

References: http://www.phy.ntnu.edu.tw/demolab/phpBB/viewtopic.php?topic=18565 http://www.phy.ntnu.edu.tw/ntnujava/index.php?topic=579.0
v.abstract: This simulation models two balls bouncing off the ground in a situation where both momentum and mechanical energy are perfectly conserved.
This simulation demonstrates the kinetic motions of N=21 uncoupled pendulums.
v.desc:
This simulation demonstrates the kinetic motions of N=21 uncoupled pendulums. The frequency difference (df) between nearby pendulums is fixed so that the lengths of the pendulums are monotonically increasing. In this simulation, the frequency of the slowest pendulum (with the longest length) is f (1/s) . The frequency of the fastest pendulum (with the shortest length) is ff (1/s). The frequency difference between the nearby pendulums is df=(ff-f)/(N-1). Students can observe the dynamics of N=21 pendulums firstly. Thereafter, adjust the number of the pendulum N from 2 to more to learn how and why the pendulums could form the wave-like motions.
Note: (a) t is the real time; CT is the time when all pendulums are swing to the same phase (line-up)
          (b) when N<9, the numbers next to pendulums are their corresponding length (cm).
          (c) g=980 cm/s^2
Variables:
N: number of pendulums
f: the frequency of the slowest pendulum (1/s)
ff: the frequency of the fastest pendulum (1/s)
To run the simulation:
Press "Play" after variables are set upon your request. Press "Reset" to stop the simulation.
data sheet:
t: time (s)
N: number of pendulums
f: the frequency of the slowest pendulum (1/s)
ff: the frequency of the fastest pendulum (1/s)
reference: 師大物理問題討論區 黃福坤教授 http://www.phy.ntnu.edu.tw/demolab/phpBB/viewtopic.php?topic=21343

This simulation models the movement of a vehicle as it initially travels at a constant velocity, then brakes. The objective: set the variable(s) so that the vehicle stops at the red stop line.  A truck moves at a constant velocity V (m/s). At position x = 0, the driver sees that there is a cat 100 meters away. The driver steps on the brakes d meters from the cat, after which the truck decelerates at a m/s^2 until it stops.

V: truck velocity (m/s)

(3)  Purple arrow: position when braking

v.desc:
This program simulates the temperature change during the cooling process of a sample whose temperature is higher than room temperature. In the simulation, it is assumed that the rate of heat loss of the sample is proportional to the temperature difference between the sample and room temperature, which is Newton's law of cooling.

ΔQ/Δt = h*A*(T-T0)  ..............(1)

ΔQ: Lost heat

t: Time

T: Sample temperature

T0: Room temperature

h: Heat conduction coefficient

A: Heat conduction surface area

According to the definition of specific heat(s), ΔQ=M*s*ΔT. You can rewrite equation (1) as

ΔT/Δt = h*A*(T-T0)/(M*s) .............(2)

For the same sample, equation (2) can be simplified to

ΔT/Δt = K*(T-T0) .............(3)

In equation (3), the rate of change of sample temperature (ΔT/Δt) is proportional to the temperature difference between the sample temperature and room temperature (T-T0). That is, when the temperature difference between the sample temperature and room temperature is larger, the rate of change of the sample temperature is larger as well.

In the simulation, the user can select two identical samples, control the starting temperature and room temperature of the two samples, and execute the simulation. Please observe the temperature changes as the samples cool down and how the change in the sample temperature relates to (T-T0). Or, by choosing different samples with the same starting temperature and room temperature to observe the relationship between temperature change and the specific heat (s) of the sample when they cool down.

Alterable parameters:

Sample A:  〇Water 100 g    〇Glycerin 100 g    〇Water 200 g    〇Glycerin 200 g   〇Sand 200 g

TA0: Initial temperature of sample A (°C)

T0A: Room A temperature (°C)

Sample B:  〇Water 100 g    〇Glycerin 100 g    〇Water 200 g    〇Glycerin 200 g   〇Sand 200 g

TB0: Initial temperature of sample B (°C)

T0B: Room  B temperature (°C)

Checkboxes:

Timed pause: When selected, the simulation pauses every 10 min in the simulation time. Please press the "Play" button after completing the data record to continue the simulation

Simulation instructions:

(1) After setting the samples and alterable parameters, press the "Play" button to perform the simulation

(2) To end the simulation, please press the "Reset" button.
v.abstract: This program simulates the temperature change during the cooling process of a sample whose temperature is higher than room temperature.

This program simulates a water flow system and an electric circuit. There are four scenarios in the simulation:

"Water flow game": There is a rectangular water channel in the screen, and there is a pokéball in the channel. There is also a waterwheel that can be driven by water flow, three pokémons, and a pump next to the water channel. Please try to make the water in the channel flow and make the pokéball move. Then, use the keyboard or click the "U(up), D(down), L(left), R(right)" keys on the screen to control the pokéball and keep it close to the edge of the water channel to capture all the pokémons.

"Electric circuit": The left half of the screen is the water flow system, and the right half is an electric circuit. The user can drag the pump and the battery in the screen to drive each system separately to observe the corresponding characteristics of components in the two systems.

"Matching game": Please drag the "Electron flow, light bulb, battery" in the screen to the red box corresponding to the device in the water flow system, and complete the corresponding pairing of the object characteristics between the two systems.

"Electron flow quiz": There are two batteries and two light bulbs in the simulation. Please design a circuit that maximizes the electron flow. 

Simulation instruction:

(1) Set the scenario

(2) Drag objects and complete tasks based on different scenario

(3) Press the "reset" button to terminate the simulation.

v.langmode0: "the red ball didn't land back on the cart"
v.langmode1: "the red ball land back on the cart"
v.desc:
This simulation models a situation where a sliding cart traveling on a flat surface launches a ball straight up after 1 second of travel. Assume that when the ball is launched, the net internal energy of the system does not change and the system is not affected. Will the ball land back on the cart?

Mass of sliding cart = 1 kg, mass of ball = 0.01 kg, mass of object pulling the cart = 1 kg, gravitational acceleration = 9.8 m/s2.

Modes: "Cart Travels at Constant Velocity": The cart slides along a flat surface with velocity Vx = 40 m/s. After 1 second, the ball is launched straight up with velocity Vy = 35 m/s. Red arrows represent the vertical and horizontal velocities of the ball; the green arrow represents the horizontal velocity of the cart. "Cart Accelerates": The cart slides along a flat surface with initial velocity Vx = 40 m/s and is accelerated by a heavy object connected to it by a string. After 1 second, the ball is launched straight up with velocity Vy = 35 m/s.

Instructions:

Buttons: Cart Travels at Constant Velocity, Cart Accelerates, Show Path, Show Position After Each Second

  1. Choose a mode: “Cart Travels at Constant Velocity” or “Cart Accelerates”

  2. Click Play to run simulation. Click Reset to choose a different mode and run the simulation again.

  3. To show the positions of the cart and the ball each second, check “trace.”

Students can observe the motions of the ball and the cart in each scenario and generalize concepts about projectile motion. Students can also observe the ball and the cart separately and discuss the nature of their motions.

v.desc: The program simulates the magnetic field generated by a magnet bar. The program also simulates the field direction, magnetic field lines, and the intensity distribution of the field. You can drag and move the compasses at the bottom-left corner at the simulation (maximum number of 10) to measure the direction of the needle and the intensity of the field (unit: 10-4 T) at the center of the compasses. When the “yellow” compass is moved again, an arrow which indicates the direction of the magnetic field remains at the original location. You can drag and move the yellow compass multiple times to observe and record the magnetic field direction at different locations.

The program simulates the change in the observed frequency when there is a relative movement between the wave source and the observer.
v.desc:
The program simulates the change in the observed frequency when there is a relative movement between the wave source and the observer. In the simulation, there is an ambulance generating a sound wave every two seconds (0.5 Hz). The wave propagates at 40 m/s. The pink circle represents the wavefront of each sound wave. When the wave propagates to the position of the observer, the observer changes color into purple. Please turn on the speaker on your device to hear the difference in frequency and volume of the sound. You can also use the stopwatch in the simulation to calculate the time interval between each sound wave reaching the observer. Please experiment with the velocity of the ambulance and the observer to compare the difference in sound frequency when there is relative movement and when there is not.

Alterable parameters:
Vcar: The velocity of the ambulance (m/s)
Vp: The velocity of the observer

Options: (Changes the scene of the simulation.)
Streets scene: Select to show the street scene with an ambulance and observer during the simulation.
Hear the sound: Select to only show a human head the sound heard by the observer.

Checkboxes:
Stopwatch: Click to show the stopwatch which indicates the time interval between the sound waves (i.e. the time period of the sound heard by the observer). 
Hide wavefronts: Click to hide the displayed wavefront (pink circles).

Instructions: Set the alterable parameters (Vcar, Vp, and checkboxes) and press “Play” to start the simulation. Press “Reset” to end the simulation.

Note: Since the audio file wasn’t processed continuously, there will be a short period of discontinuity after the observer encounters the sound source.

v.langmode0: "simulation paused! click Play button to drop down the sample on the right "
v.desc:
﻿The program simulates the buoyancy experienced by different objects when they are submerged in liquids. There are two types of materials to choose from: aluminum(density: 2.7 g/cm3) and wood(density: 0.5 g/cm3). For each material, there are two samples each with different shapes and volumes. You can adjust the density of the liquids on both sides individually and choose different samples to hang under the hand-held scales. When the simulation begins, the samples drop down slowly into the liquids below. Without setting the “Comparison modes”, the simulation doesn’t pause automatically and the samples continue to move downwards after they are submerged into the liquids. Please compare the behavior of two different samples when they are submerged in liquids of identical densities. Also, compare the behavior of two identical samples when they are submerged in liquids of different densities.

To investigate whether the submerged depth of the sample affects buoyancy, set the comparison mode to “Submerged depth” and select the aluminum blocks as the test samples. Under this mode, the simulation pauses automatically after both samples drop down 5 cm. To continue the simulation, click the “Play” button in the upper-left corner. The sample on the right drops down to a lower position while the sample on the left remains in the same position. Compare the data on both sides to see whether the submerged depth of an object affects the buoyancy. You can also select samples with different shapes and drop them to the same depth to see whether the shape of an object affects the buoyancy.

  To investigate whether the submerged volume of an object affects the buoyancy, set the comparison mode to “Submerged volume”. In this mode, the samples drop down until half of the volume is submerged in the liquid, and then the simulation pauses. To continue the simulation, click the “Play” button in the upper-left corner. The sample on the right drops down to a lower position while the sample on the left remains in the same position. Compare the data on both sides to see whether the submerged volume of an object affects the buoyancy. You can also experiment with fluids with different densities to see whether the liquid density affects buoyancy.

 

Alterable parameters:
DsL: The liquid density in the left-hand side tank (g/cm3)
Sample on the left: A, B (Aluminum blocks with the same volume but different shapes), C, D (Wooden blocks with identical shapes but different volumes)

DsR: The liquid density in the right-side tank (g/cm3)
Sample on the right: A, B (Aluminum blocks with the same volume but different shapes), C, D (Wooden blocks with identical shapes but different volume) 

Comparison modes:
Not choosing: The simulation continues without pausing automatically 

“Submerged depth”: The simulation automatically pauses after the aluminum blocks drop down by 5 cm. The sample on the left remains in the same position. After clicking “Play”, the sample on the right drops down deeper, and the simulation pauses again. 

“Submerged volume”: The simulation automatically pauses after the samples drop down to half of the height of the sample. The sample on the left remains in the same position. After clicking “Play”, the sample on the right continues to drop down until it is completely submerged. The simulation pauses again after the sample on the right is completely submerged. 

Checkboxes:

Submerged volume of the sample: Indicated with a number (red)
Buoyancy: Indicated with an arrow and a number (pink)
Gravity: Indicated with an arrow (green)
Add an underwater scale: Add a scale at the bottom of the tank 

Instructions:
(1)Set the parameters such as liquid densities and the samples (A, B, C, D) on both sides.
(2)Select the “Comparison modes” (optional)
(3)Click on the checkboxes to display the desired information (This step can also be done during the simulation. However, nothing will be displayed if this step is done when the simulation is paused)
(4)Press “Play” to execute the simulation. To pause and observe the simulation halfway, press “Pause”.
(5)To stop the simulation, press ”Reset”

v.desc:
This program simulates the trajectory of an object being tossed out at the edge of a turntable (rotating with constant speed) in different coordinates. In the simulation, there is a turntable rotating with constant angular velocity w. Ash Ketchum stands at the edge of the turntable while holding a Pokeball, and Pikachu is at the center of the turntable. After the simulation is executed (after pressing "Play"), the user can press the "launch" button to make Ash throw the Pokeball towards the Pikachu (red dotted arrow) at a constant speed. Can you figure out whether Ash can make the Pokeball reach and catch the Pikachu by aiming in the direction towards it? Where will the Pokeball reach in the end? Directly in front of Pikachu, forward right to Ash, or forward left to Ash? Will Misty, who stands on the ground, observe the same Pokeball trajectory as Pikachu, which stands on the turntable? How will the trajectory of the Pokeball and the position of the landing point change when the turntable rotates counterclockwise or clockwise?

Alterable parameters: 

Observer position: Options "Ground (Inertial frame)" or “Turntable" 

w: Angular velocity of turntable (w>0 counterclockwise rotation；w<0 clockwise Rotation)   

Checkboxes: 

The trajectory of every second: Check to show the trajectory of the Pokeball every second after it is thrown. 

Inertial coordinate: When selected, the inertial coordinate axes (black dotted arrows) are shown after the Pokeball is thrown out.

Button:   ----- launch ----- Press this button to launch the Pokeball in the aimed direction. 

Simulation instruction:

(1) Press “Play” to execute the simulation 

(2) Set the alterable parameters.     

(3) press "Launch" to throw the Pokeball in the aimed direction 

(4) When the Pokeball reaches the edge of the round table, a message pops up, and the simulation will reset after the message is closed.  

Simulation display:

Light blue arrow: tangential velocity of the Pokeball

Red dotted arrow: the aimed (velocity) direction when the Pokeball is launched

Purple arrow: The moving (velocity) direction of the Pokeball (light blue arrow + red dotted arrow)

This simulation models a 1-dimensional collision between two balls under different specifications (perfectly elastic, inelastic, and perfectly inelastic).
v.desc:
1-Dimensional Collision: This simulation models a 1-dimensional collision between two balls under different specifications (elastic, inelastic, and perfectly inelastic).

The coefficient of restitution Cr is defined:

Cr=(Ub-Ua)/(Va-Vb)

where
Ua=((Ma-Cr*Mb)/(Ma+Mb))*Va+(((Cr+1)*Mb)/(Ma+Mb))*Vb
Ub=(((1+Cr)*Ma)/(Ma+Mb))*Va+((Mb-Cr*Ma)/(Ma+Mb))*Vb

Settings:

Cr = 1 : elastic collision

Cr = 0.5 : inelastic collision

Cr = 0 : perfectly inelastic collision

Students can explore the behavior of the two balls after collision under different conditions and the effect of mass on movement. What values in the system remain the same before and after the collision?

Alterable Variables:

Ma: mass of red ball (g)

Mb: mass of green ball (g)

Va: velocity of red ball (cm/s) Vb: velocity of green ball (cm/s)

Instructions:

  1. Specify the type of reaction: Elastic, Inelastic, Perfectly Inelastic

  2. Set variables (Ma, Mb, Va, Vb) to desired values and click Play to run simulation. Click Reset to end simulation.

  3. Click “Show center of mass and velocity”

You can adjust the angle and speed of the purple astronaut's bullet, and your advantage is that you will shoot 3 seconds after the game starts. Can you prevent the purple astronaut from being shot? v.Vu_comment: "volume of the block submerged in solution"
v.desc:
This simulation models the process of putting an orange block of mass M (g) and volume V (cm3) into a blue solution with density rhoS (g/cm3). At the beginning, the block is held above the solution by the hand. when simulation plays, the block will be lowered slowly down into the solution below. The liquid displaced by the block is collected in the beaker to the left (the volume of which is equivalent to the block’s volume). The yellow scale under the beaker measures the mass of the displaced liquid. There is also a gray scale at the bottom of the container. Students can change the densities of the block and the solution and observe the behavior of the block as it enters the solution. Can you figure out the buoyancy experienced by the block from the readings of the three scales?

Note: The mass and volume of the string and hook are assumed to be negligibly small.

Alterable Variables:
rhoS: density of blue solution (g/cm3)
V: volume of orange block (cm3)
M: mass of orange block (g)

Checkboxes:
gravitational force: show vector representation of the gravitational force or weight of the block
buoyancy: show vector representation of the buoyancy exerted on the block

 

Instructions:
(1) Set the alterable variables V, M, and rhoS to desired values.
(2) Click "Play" to run the simulation.
(3) Using the Pause/Play button, observe the readings of the three scales. While paused, the contents of the beaker can be dragged around. Drag the contents of the beaker to the orange block and take note of the relationship between the mass of the displaced solution (the reading of the yellow scale) and buoyancy. The contents of the beaker will automatically return to the beaker when you click Play.
(4) Click "Reset" to end the simulation.
v.abstract: This simulation models the process of putting an orange block of mass M (g) and volume V (cm^3) into a blue solution with density rhoS (g/cm^3) in order to investigate the concept of buoyancy.

v.ml_infoTitle: Frictional and centripetal forces- Car rounding a curv
v.desc:
This simulation models the motion of a car rounding a banked curve at a constant speed. Users can choose the type of road to be a frictionless road or asphalt road. The friction coefficient between the tyre and asphalt road is 0.8. Users can also set the car speed V and the bank angle of the curve. Let’s try to find out if the car can negotiate the curve with a radius of 25m; what is the maximum speed the car can travel on a given type of road at a bank angle?

Question 1: On an unbanked frictionless road, is it possible to keep the car going around the curve? If it is, what is the speed of the car?

Question 2: On a banked and frictionless road, is it possible to keep the car going around the banked curve? If it is, what is the speed of the car?

Question 3: On an unbanked asphalt road, is it possible to keep the car traveling around the curve? If it is, what is the maximum speed the car should travel?

Question 4: On a banked asphalt road, is it possible to keep the car traveling around the banked curve.? If it is, what is the maximum speed the car should travel?

Question 5: How much is the friction force acting on the car tyre and what is the direction of the friction force while the car is traveling?

 

Multiple choice of road:

Frictionless road: The friction coefficient between the road and the tyre is 0.

Asphalt road: The friction coefficient between the road and the tyre is 0.8.

 

Alterable variables: 

theta: Bank angle

V: car speed (km/hr)

 

Checkboxes: 

Centripetal force: Show a vector that represents the direction of centripetal force

Free-body diagram: Show vectors that represent forces acting on the car.

 

Instruction:

(1) Set a road type, alterable variables, and checkboxes, then click “Play” to run the simulation.  

(2) After the simulation pauses, click “Reset” to end the simulation.

This simulation models the path of a bomb that is dropped from a moving airplane.  Aim for the radar station on the ground.
v.desc:
This simulation models the path of a bomb that is dropped from a moving airplane. An airplane flies at an altitude H meters above the ground with velocity Vx m/s. A bomb is dropped from the plane at a (horizontal) distance of 400 meters away from the radar station on the ground. Students are to set the variables H and Vx so that the bomb hits the radar station when it reaches the ground. Students should observe (1) the horizontal and vertical movements of the bomb as it falls, (2) the factors that affect the time it takes for the bomb to land, and (3) the factors that determine whether the bomb hits or misses the radar station.
Notes: (1) Gravitational acceleration g = 10 m/s2. (2) In the simulation, when the bomb lands at a position |x - 400| ≤ 5, the target is considered “hit.” At a position 5 < |x - 400| ≤ 18, it is considered an “almost-hit”--keep trying. At a position |x - 400| > 18, it is considered a “miss.”

Alterable variables:
H: flying altitude (meters)
Vx: flying velocity (m/s)

Checkboxes:
“Show position after each second”: check this box (prior to clicking Play) to show where the bomb is at each second.
“Show velocity”: check this box (prior to clicking Play) to show velocity vectors of the bomb.

This simulation models a transverse wave traveling toward the right with speed V cm/s. The wave is sinusoidal, with its position (x) changing with time (t), and with equation:

y(x,t)=A*sin(k*x-w*t)=A*sin[(2*pi/la)*x-(2*pi/T)*t]

A: amplitude

k: wavenumber

w: angular frequency

la: wavelength (la = 2*pi/k)

T: period (T = 2*pi/w)

V: speed (V = w/k)

The upper half of the simulation depicts the waveform in a y(x,t)-x graph. The lower half of the simulation depicts the position of a point P on the wave with respect to time in a Py(t)-t graph. Students can change the amplitude, wavelength, and period of the wave. Click Play to run simulation.

Alterable Variables:

A: amplitude (cm)

la: wavelength (cm)

T: period (s)

Instructions:

Set variables to desired values and click Play to run simulation. Click Reset to end simulation.

Display: Green arrow: wave speed V
v.abstract: This simulation models a transverse wave traveling toward the right with a speed of V cm/s. Students can change the amplitude, wavelength, and period of the wave to observe their effects on the waveform.

v.desc:
This program simulates motions of two objects of equal weight being submerged into water。There are three crowns (all weighted 1000 grams)in this simulation；one is made of pure gold and the other two are alloys。One the right hand side of the lever hangs a pieces of pure gold (1000 grams)。Can you tell which of these crowns (A， B， C) is made of pure gold? What are the densities of three crowns? 

To run the simulation:
(1)Chose crown (A，B，C)
(2)Press "Play" to run the simulation，press "Reset" to end the simulation
checkbox: check to use measurement tools

To determine whether a crown was made of pure gold, Greek philosopher Archimedes introduced the concept of buoyancy--that the buoyant force on an object is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. However, Archimedes did not record in his works how, exactly, he used the concept of buoyancy to determine whether the crown was made of pure gold. Later scholars pointed out that the amount of fluid displaced by a crown doped with silver and that by a crown made of pure gold would not differ greatly, and that the technology from Archimedes's time would not have been precise enough to determine a difference. After reading Archimedes's works, Galilei proposed that Archimedes might have combined the concept of buoyancy and the use of levers to solve the problem.

This simulation models the image formation of a blue arrow-shaped object placed in front of a mirror.
v.desc:
This simulation models the image formation of a blue arrow-shaped object placed in front of a plane mirror, a convex mirror, or a concave mirror. Users can drag the arrow object in front of the mirror horizontally to observe the image formed behind the mirror. Rays diverging from the two ends of the arrow are reflected by the mirror. The virtual image observed by the eyes is the collection of focus points made by the extension of the reflected rays. Furthermore, users can observe how are the properties of the image such as size, orientation, and distance related to those of the object. In the simulation, a real image is represented by a light blue arrow drawn as a solid line. A virtual image is represented by a light blue arrow drawn as a dashed line. Convex and concave mirrors are both a portion of a spherical mirror. The orange dot represents the focal point.

Instruction:
(1) Choose the type of mirror: Plane mirror/ Convex mirror/ Concave mirror.
(2) Drag the arrow-shaped object (Blue) horizontally to observe the image.
(3) Select a radio button: None/ static ray diagram/ dynamic ray diagram.
(4) Buttons: Zoom in/ Zoom out.
Click “Zoom in” or “Zoom out” to adjust the field of view.

This simulation models the process of two shooters operating two different slingshots as they firstly pull rubber bands back and then release the projectiles. In the simulation, there are three modes of operating the slingshot. Mode “Customize” is for exploring the relationship between the draw force and the displacement of the rubber band; Mode “Fixed maximum draw force” and Mode “Fixed displacement” are for exploring the concept of the work-energy theorem from the speed of the projectile which is converted from the work done by the shooter to pull the slingshot. Users can choose to make graphs that show the relationship between draw force and displacement of the rubber band. Compare differences in slope on the graph for the two slingshots and figure out how to calculate the spring constant for them.

In the simulation, the spring constant of the rubber band A is 25 N/m and that of rubber band B is 50 N/m

Instruction:
If the operating mode is set to “Customize”:
(1) Click “Customize”
(2) Choose to make a graph.
(3) Set values for force F gradually from 0 to 20. According to the value F, the simulation will show the displacements of the two slingshots.
(4) Click “Reset” to end the simulation

If the operating mode is set to “Fixed maximum draw force” or “Fixed displacement”:
(1) Click “Fixed maximum draw force” or “Fixed displacement”
(2)  Choose to make a graph
(3) Click “Play” to run the simulation. The simulation will show the process of shooters pulling back rubber bands and releasing the projectiles.
(4) Click “Reset” to end the simulation, and then set the mode of pulling back the rubber band to observe the simulation with different settings again.

Settings:
Modes of operating the slingshot:

”Customize”: for exploring the relationship between the draw force (F) and the displacement (dx) of the rubber band.
"Fixed maximum draw force” mode: With the increase of the draw forces done by two shooters, the projectiles will be released when the draw force reaches the maximum magnitude of 20N.
"Fixed displacement” mode: With the increase of the displacement of the two rubber bands, the projectiles will be released when the displacement of both slingshots reaches a value of 0.5m (50cm)

 Make a graph:
"None”: show nothing
"Draw force vs. Displacement”: X-axis is the displacement and Y-axis is the draw force
"Displacement vs. Draw force”: X-axis is the draw force and Y-axis is the draw length

This simulation models the free-falling processes of two objects with different shapes and masses in both air and a vacuum.
v.desc:
This simulation models the free-falling processes of two objects with different masses and shapes from a height H = 125 m, both in air and in a vacuum. The container on the left is filled with air, and the container on the right is a vacuum. In the left “corner” of each container is a red sphere with mass Ma, and students can choose an object to place in the right “corner” of each container (blue cube, toy parachute, feather, or green ball).

Objects free-falling in air are subject to the forces of gravity (downwards Fg = -m*g) and air resistance (upwards FD). The force of air resistance depends on the shape, cross section, and mass of an object. In general, FD can be defined as

FD = 0.5*CD*ρ*A*v2 = k*v2         (CD: drag coefficient; ρ: air density; A: cross section)

The CD of the objects in the simulation are:
Red sphere: 0.5
Blue cube: 1.05
Parachute: 1.42
Feather: 2

F = m*a = Fg + FD= -m*g + k*v2

m*(dv/dt) = -m*g+ k*v2

(dv/dt) = -g + k*v2/ m

The motion of the objects can be modeled by the following equations:

F = m*a = Fg + FD= -m*g + k*v2

m*(dv/dt) = -m*g+ k*v2

(dv/dt) = -g + k*v2/ m

When the force of gravity is equal to the force of air resistance, the falling velocity of an object becomes constant. This velocity is called the terminal velocity.

F=m * dv/dt = m*a = -m*g

dv/dt = -g

Within a vacuum, the only force acting on all 4 objects is gravity. According to Newton’s Second Law, the acceleration of a falling object is a fixed value (gravitational acceleration g = 9.8 m/s2).

F=m * dv/dt = m*a = -m*g

dv/dt = -g

As such, the 4 objects will land at the same time within a vacuum.
Alterable variable:
Ma: mass of red sphere (g)
Buttons: “Blue cube (500 g)”; “Toy parachute (200 g)”; “Feather (50 g)” ; “Green ball (200 g)”
Checkboxes: “Gravity”; “Air resistance”; “Position each second”, Check these boxes to show; uncheck to hide

Instructions: Select the object (blue cube, toy parachute, feather, or green ball), set Ma to desired value, and click Play to run the simulation. Click Reset to end the simulation.

This program simulates pressure measured at a given position within a fluid. In the simulation, there are five containers of different shapes. v.plottingPanel-20_tabName: "mechanical energy after the bullet being shot into pendulum"
v.desc:
In 1742, English mathematician Benjamin Robins invented a ballistic pendulum for the purpose of measuring the velocity of a bullet, exemplifying the concept of a perfectly inelastic collision. Robins shot a bullet at a metal pendulum, the surface of which is covered by a piece of cork wood so that the bullet became lodged on the pendulum, moving at the same velocity as the pendulum. Because mechanical energy and momentum are conserved, knowing the height to which the pendulum swings and the mass of the pendulum (metal + cork + bullet), it is possible to calculate the speed of the bullet. Robins’s method does not require a timer, but is no less accurate. This simulation models the process as a bullet with mass Mb is shot at a velocity Vb and embedded into a rubber pendulum (mass Mp at the end of a 150 cm string) in a perfectly inelastic collision. (g = 9.8 m/s^2)

Alterable Variables:

Vb: velocity of bullet (m/s)

Mb: mass of bullet (g)

Mp: mass of pendulum (kg)

Instructions:

Set your variables (Vb, Mb, Mp) and click "Play" to run simulation. Click "Reset" to end simulation. After changing the values of the variables, click Play to run next simulation.

Variables in Table:

Vb: velocity of bullet (m/s)

Mb: mass of bullet (g)

Mp: mass of pendulum (kg)

H: maximum height of pendulum (cm)

C: maximum angle of pendulum (degrees)
v.abstract: This simulation models a scenario where a bullet is shot at a velocity Vb into a pendulum, based upon the ballistic pendulum devised by English mathematician Benjamin Robins in 1742.

v.ml_infoTitle: Projectile Motion VS Free Fall-Crack Shot
v.desc:
Description: This simulation explores the horizontal and vertical components of an object during projectile motion. An apple has a starting position at coordinates (125, 150). Gravitational acceleration is assumed to be g = 10 m/s^2. A crack shot aims his gun at the apple, which will begin to free fall when he pulls the trigger. How can he make sure, through the velocity of his bullet and the angle of his shot, that his bullet will hit the apple?
Alterable Variables:
Modes: Horizontal Shot or Angled Shot
V: initial velocity of bullet (m/s)
theta: angle of shot (degrees)

(1) Horizontal Shot: The crack shot’s gun, with coordinates (0, 150), is at the same height as the apple. The gun is aimed horizontally at the apple (theta = 0). How can the crack shot be sure that his bullet will hit the apple? If the bullet must hit the apple before the apple lands on the ground, what restraints are placed upon the bullet's velocity? Instructions: Choose “Horizontal Shot,” set bullet velocity V, and click Play.
(2) Angled Shot:
(a) The crack shot shoots from the ground at coordinates (0, 0). If he aims his gun at the apple’s initial position, can he hit the apple? If he wants to hit the apple before it lands on the ground, how must he adjust his bullet’s velocity? Instructions: Choose “Angled Shot,” set bullet velocity V and angle of shot theta = 50 (aimed at the apple), and click Play.
(b) The crack shot shoots from the ground at coordinates (0, 0). If he does not aim his gun at the apple’s initial position, can he hit the apple? Instructions: Choose “Angled Shot,” set bullet velocity V and angle of shot theta, and click Play

Display:
Apple: free fall
Red arrow: apple velocity
Pink dots: second-by-second dot diagram of apple’s position
Black circle: bullet
Black arrow: bullet velocity
Gray dots: second-by-second dot diagram of bullet’s position
Blue line: gun aim

v.ml_infoTitle: Simplfied model of land and see breeze
v.desc:
The simulation uses a simple temperature-pressure model to simulate the formation of sea and land breezes and changes in wind direction. Users can select a time button to set the time and check the measurements checkboxes to observe the changes in pressure and wind direction. There is a cruise ship off the coast with a chimney that smokes continuously and shows the direction and strength of the wind close to the surface of land and sea. The temperature on land is "Tland”, the temperature of the sea surface is "Tsea”, and the temperature difference between the land and the sea is Tdiff=Tland-Tsea.

 Time options:
All day: Select this option to observe the dynamic change throughout the day. Press “Play” at the top left to start the simulation. Check the measurement checkboxes to observe the daily variation of sea breeze and land breeze.
8:00 AM: Select this option to observe the scenario at 8 A.M. The temperature of the land and the sea is the same and there is no breeze at this time. Check the measurement checkboxes to observe the spatial distribution of pressure and the contours of the isobars.
2:00 PM: Select this option to observe the scenario at 14:00. The temperature difference between the land and the sea is the largest at this time (Tdiff = 12 oC). Check the measurement checkboxes to observe the spatial distribution of pressure near the surface of the land and the sea and the pressure at high altitudes. Try to explore the cause of the breeze and its direction.
2:00 AM: Select this option to observe the scenario at 2 A.M. The difference in temperature at this time is Tdiff = -7 oC. Check the measurement checkboxes to observe the spatial distribution of pressure near the surface of the land and the sea and the pressure at high altitudes. Try to explore the cause of the breeze and its direction. 

Checkboxes:
Barometer: Click to display two barometers in the "All Day" scenario and four barometers in other scenarios. Drag and drop the barometers to measure the pressure at different locations.  
Altitude reference: Click to show the altitude reference lines.
Wind field diagram: Click to dispaly the schematic wind field diagram. In the "All Day" scenario, the wind field indicator arrows will be displayed only when the sea and land winds are forming, and the length of the arrows indicates the strength of the wind. In the "8:00" scenario, no wind field is formed, so even if this option is checked, it is still not displayed on the screen. In the "2:00PM" and "2:00AM" scenarios, the wind field indicator arrows are presented in a dynamic manner, indicating the sequence and direction of air movement during wind field formation. The color of the arrows represents the change in temperature as the air moves, with red being hot and blue being cold.
Isobars: Click to show the isobars.

Simple temperature-pressure model:

According to the atmospheric pressure model in hydrostatic equilibrium, when the average temperature of the air column is T, the variation of air pressure with altitude follows the equation below:

p(z)=p(z=0)*exp(-z*g/(R*T))        (eq. 1)

R=287.05 (J*Kg-1*K-1)，g=9.8(m/s2)

When the temperature of the land and the sea are identical (8 A.M. and 8 P.M.), the isobars are horizontal. At the same altitude, the pressure on the sea is the same as on the land. Hence, there is no wind since there is no pressure difference.

When the surface of the land heats up at a faster rate, according to (eq.1), the change rate of the pressure to the altitude of the land (which is warmer) is slower than that of the sea (which is colder). That is, at the same height, the pressure of the land is higher than that of the sea at higher altitudes. Furthermore, due to the rise of the heated air close to the surface of the land, the pressure close to the ground is lowered. Hence, the pressure of the land is lower than the pressure of the sea at sea level. As for the profile of the isobars, when the temperature of the ground is higher than the temperature at the surface of the sea, the gaps between the isobars on the land side are wider. The isobars are more spread out compared to the colder surface of the sea (similar to the situation of 14:00). When the horizontal pressure difference between the land and the sea is larger than a specific value, land and sea breezes in medium scales (ranging from few kilometers to dozens of kilometer) begins to form. In the simulation, only if the temperature difference is larger than 6 oC (10 A.M.-6 P.M./ 0 A.M.- 4 A.M.) and the pressure difference is larger than 12 hPa does the wind field forms. The wind field forms when the heated air packet near the ground rises and the pressure at higher altitudes on the land side is larger than on the sea side. The air packets move from the land side to the sea side. That is, at higher altitudes, the wind blows from land to sea. At the same time, the pressure of the ground is lower than the pressure of the sea surface close to sea level and the air packets move from the sea side to the land side due to the pressure difference. Hence, close to sea level, the wind blows from the sea side to the land side (sea breeze). Due to the continuity of the fluid, a circulating wind field is formed.

After the night falls, the temperature of the land side decreases faster. According to (eq.1) and the argument above, the change rate of pressure to altitude is larger at the higher altitudes of the cooler land side. Hence, at the same height, the pressure of the land side is lower than the sea side at higher altitudes. At the same time, the pressure of the ground is higher than the pressure of the sea surface close to sea level. As for the profile of the isobars, when the temperature of the ground is lower than the surface of the sea, the gaps between the isobars on the land side are narrower. The isobars are tighter compared to the hotter surface of the sea (similar to the situation of 02:00). Therefore, at higher altitudes, the pressure at the sea side is larger than the pressure on the land side and wind blows from the sea side to the land side. Close to the sea level, the pressure of the sea side is lower than that of the land side and the wind blows from the land side

v.abstract: The program simulates a little green man using a bow and arrow to make a shot
v.desc:
The program simulates a little green man using a bow and arrow to make a shot. In the simulation, the little green man is holding a toy bow. You can adjust how hard the green figure draws the bow. The spring constant of the toy bow and the mass of the arrow are adjustable too. The objective of the simulation is to make the arrow hit the center of the target. As the green figure draws the bow, the force pulling on the string bends the bow and does work, storing energy in the bow in the form of elastic potential energy. As the string is released, the elastic potential energy of the bow is converted into the kinetic energy of the arrow. The arrow gains velocity and shoots towards the target. In the simulation, we assume the bow and arrow as a spring-mass system. When the little green man applied force (F) to the bow and pull back on the string with a draw displacement(x), the relationship between F and x is  F=-k*x. k is the effective spring constant of the bow. It is also assumed that all the elastic potential energy (Us=1/2*k*x2) stored in the bow converts into the kinetic energy (1/2*m*V2)of the arrow. 

Instructions

(1)   Set the alterable parameters.
(2)   Select the needed functions by clicking on the checkboxes.
(3)   Press the “Play” button to start the simulation.
(4)   Press the “Reset” button to stop the simulation.

Alterable parameter
F: The maximum force on the bow
K: The spring constant of the bow
M: The mass of the arrow 

Checkboxes:
“Pause at fixed positions when drawing the bow”: For easier observation, the simulation pauses automatically every time the string of the bow is pulled back by 0.1 m. To continue the simulation, press the “Play” button.
“data”: Click to show the data for observation.
“No gravity”: Click to remove the gravity in the simulation.

v.desc:
This program simulates the resistance of different materials when connected to the circuit. The simulation includes a circuit consisting of a battery, a light bulb (with a resistance of 5 Ω when powered on), and two alligator clips. Users can drag objects (one at a time) on the left side of the simulation screen to place them between the alligator clips to form a closed circuit to observe changes of electric current with objects made of different materials in the circuit and their resistance characteristics. when the mechanical pencil lead is placed in the circuit, users can drag the alligator clip at the right to change clipping position. They can observe the current change at different measured lengths and explore the relationship between measured length and resistance value. Resistance is proportional to length in the simulation. For a thick pencil lead (0.2mm), the resistance is 4 ohms at a length of 10 cm. For a thin pencil lead (0.1mm), the resistance is 16 ohms at a length of 10 cm.

Simulation instructions:

(1) Click and drag an object on the left side of the screen and place it between the two alligator clips.

(2) You can select "Ammeter", "Electron Flow", or "Ruler" to observe or measure.

(3) After measuring, please drag the object back to the left side of the screen before dragging other objects.
v.abstract: This program simulates the resistance of different materials when connected to the circuit.

v.ml_infoTitle: get wetter if you run ? E
v.desc:
This program simulates one giant running in the rain from eaves m to eaves n with different speed and calculates how many raindrops will he catch。In the simulation we assume the body volume of the giant as rectangular blocks。Raindrops fall vertically(no wind) onto the giant with a constant velocity (terminal speed 6 m/s)。The density of the rain shower is assumed to be uniform in space and time。

"Will I get wetter if I run in the rain?" is an interesting question to ask。This simulation demonstrate raindrops fall on  the top/ front side/ the whole body of the giant. Can you answer the following questions before/after you run this simulation? 

1.Will the number of raindrop falling on the top of the giant increase/decrease/keep the same when the giant run faster? Why?
2. Will the number of raindrop falling on the front side of the giant increase/decrease/keep the same when the giant run faster? Why?
3. Will the number of raindrop falling on the whole body of the giant increase/decrease/keep the same when the giant run faster? Why?


To run the simulation:
(1) Set the running velocity V of the giant
(2) press "Play" to run the simulation and press "Reset" to terminate
The light blue rectangles shown on the giants represent the amount of raindrops on the top；The blue rectangles shown on the giants represent the amount of raindrops on the front side。

v.langmode0: "Please put samples on the heating racks!"
v.langmode1: "Please record your data。To resume the simulation, please click Play button!"
v.desc:
This program simulates the process of heating different samples using a fixed heat source, and the process of cooling down after the heat source is removed. The alcohol burner in the simulation provides a fixed heating source to heat the sample at a rate of 300 cal/min (Q=300). After being heated continuously for a heat_t minutes, the alcohol burner will be removed (Q=0). Then the system cools down for 10 min and the simulation ends. The temperature of the sample (T) during heating and the changes in temperature (dT) follow the relationships below:

dT=T-T0 (T0 = 25 oC room temperature)

d(dT)/dt=(Q*eff-C*dT)/(m*S) .............(1)

When the first term on the right of Eq.(1) Q*eff (the heat source) exists, the heat source heats the sample, and its temperature increases.

Q: Heating rate of the heat source     Absorbed heat: H=Q*t

eff: The coefficient of effective heat conduction from the heat source to the sample. Here it is (0.9*(1/50)*t). In the beginning, about 10% of the heat is absorbed by the experimental instruments rather than the sample itself.

In Eq.(1), the second term on the right is the heat dissipation caused by the temperature difference between the sample and the room.

C: Heat conduction correlation coefficient.

m: Sample mass

S: Sample specific heat

The specific heat of the five samples in the simulation are:
water: 1.0 cal/(g*oC)    Aluminum block: 0.22 cal/(g*oC)  Glycerin: 0.58 cal/(g*oC)  Sand: 0.2 cal/( g*oC)

The user can select two different samples and place them on two heating racks to compare the temperature changes of the two samples under the same heating and cooling conditions. The teacher can guide students to select samples, design experiments, and observe and compare the differences in temperature changes between the two samples. The teacher can also introduce the definition of specific heat, and compare the order of specific heat between samples.

Alterable parameters:
heat_t: Heating time (min)
Experimental modes:
"Heating only": The experimental mode only shows the heating process till the set heating time heat_t then the simulation stops.
"Heating and cooling": In this experimental mode, the sample heats up for heat_t minutes, then the heat source is removed. Then, the sample is left to cool down for 10 min.

Environment:
Ideal: Heat offered by the burner is 100% absorbed by the sample and there is no heat loss to surroundings(thermal-isolated) . The coefficient of effective heat conduction from the heat source to the sample equals to 1. The condition fit equation  H=m*s*ΔT
Non-insulated: Heat offered by the burner is absorbed partially buy racks and beakers. There is also heat loss because the system is not thermal-insulated(room temperature is 25°C).  The coefficient of effective heat conduction from the heat source to the sample equals is smaller than 1.
Low temperature: Heat offered by the burner is absorbed partially buy racks and beakers. There is also heat loss because the system is not thermal-insulated(room temperature is 4°C).  The coefficient of effective heat conduction from the heat source to the sample equals is smaller than 1.

Single choose options (Sample on the heating rack):
Heating rack A: water100g  water200g  Lead block100g  Glycerin100g    Sand200g
Heating rack B: water100g  water200g  Lead block100g  Glycerin100g    Sand200g

Simulation instruction:
(1)Set the heating time and experiment mode
(2)Select the samples to be placed on the heating rack A, B
(3)Press "Play" to start the simulation; press "Pause" to pause the simulation(for observation or recording of the data); press "Reset" to reset the simulation

Simulation display:
Purple dotted line: The initial temperature of the sample(Room temperature)
Red dotted line: The temperature of the sample when it is heated over heat_t minutes.
Blue dotted line: the temperature of the sample after cooling for 10 minutes.

v.desc:
This program simulates the dynamics of a pyrotechnic star (600 grams) as it is launched into the sky and explodes into two parts at the highest point of its trajectory. Assume that the firework splits due solely to internal forces and that no external forces enter the system. In the simulation, students can control the mass (ma), horizontal velocity (topvxa), and vertical velocity (topvya) of the yellow piece of the firework once it splits. Students can then observe the trajectories of the two pieces of the firework and the center of mass of the system.(The gravitational acceleration g=10 m/s2)。

Variable:
ma: mass of the yellow piece 
topvxa: horizontal velocity of the yellow piece 
topvya: vertical velocity of the yellow piece 

To run the simulation:
(1) choose mode of launching the star:
"launch vertically": pyrotechnic star is launched vertically into the sky with a initial velocity V=60 m/s
"launch at an angle: pyrotechnic star is launched vertically into the sky with a initial velocity V=60 m/s at its elevation angle of 75 degree
(2) set variables (ma, topvxa, topvya)
(3) press "Play" to run the simulation and "Reset" to end the simulation
checkbox: check to show trajectory of center of the mass of the system

v.mu_comment: "friction coefficient between the road and car tires"
v.desc:
This program simulates the motion of a car traveling on a curved road at a fixed speed V (km/hr) under different weather conditions. The radius of the curved road is 25 m. To keep the car traveling safely through the curve, the car needs a centripetal force to change its course. This centripetal force is provided by the friction between the road surface and car tires. In different weather conditions, the static friction coefficient between the road surface and car tires changes.
icy road:  0.4 > mu ≥ 0.1
slippery road with rain: 0.7 > mu ≥ 0.4
dry road:  1.0 > mu ≥ 0.7
Do you know what are the maximum speeds the car can travel safely along the curved road under different weather conditions?(gravitational acceleration g=10 m/s^2)

to operation the simulation:  
(1) Set parameters V and mu
(2) press "Play" to run the simulation
(3) press "X" on the pop-up screen to reset the simulation

v.textC: "Top of truck as frame of reference"
v.desc:
This simulation models a situation where a red ball is dropped or ejected from the top of a moving truck. A truck travels with constant velocity Ve = -200 cm/s (moving to the left). At top of the rear of the truck is a red ball, which will be either dropped (V = 0 cm/s) or ejected (V > 0 cm/s) when the truck passes the black line on the ground. Take a guess: when V = 0 cm/s, 200 cm/s, and 400 cm/s, which basket will the ball fall into in each of these cases? What happens when you view the trajectory of the ball from different frames of references?

Modes:

Ground as Frame of Reference: This is the default mode; the observer views the projectile motion from the ground.

Red Ball as Frame of Reference: The observer views the motion from the ball.

Top of Truck as Frame of Reference: The observer views the motion relative to the top of the truck.


Alterable Variables:

V: the velocity of the red ball at the black line (cm/s)

Checkbox: Slow Motion: The simulation slows down after the ball is dropped or ejected.

Instructions: (1) Choose a frame of reference (2) Set V to desired value. Click "Play" to run the simulation.

(3) click "Reset" to end the simulation.

This program simulates the combining of colored lights and the mixing of paints.
v.desc:
This program simulates the combining of colored lights and the mixing of paints. On the left side of the simulation screen, there are circles representing the three primary colors of light (red, green, blue). When the user clicks and drags one of the colored lights onto another, the simulation will display the result of the light combination (color addition). On the right side of the simulation screen, there are circles representing the primary colors of paint (magenta, yellow, cyan). When the user presses and drags one of the paints onto another, the simulation will display the result of the paint mixing (color subtraction).

Simulation instructions:
(1) Please press and drag the selected circle with the mouse to the desired position and observe the color changes in different areas.
(2) To reset the simulation, please press the "Reset" button.

v.abstract: This program simulates the motion of an archer pulling a bow and shooting an arrow.
v.desc:
This program simulates the motion of an archer pulling a bow and shooting an arrow. During the simulation, the user can control the force the archer pulling the bow and the launch angle of the arrow, with the goal of hitting the bullseye on the target at the right. As the archer pulls back on the string, the pulling force does work on the bow, causing it to deform and store potential energy in the form of elastic potential energy(Us). When the string is released, this elastic potential energy is converted into the kinetic energy(Ek) of the arrow, giving it speed as it is launched. Selecting the "Graphs" box allows the user to observe the variations in work done by the force and the energy during the process. Users can observe and investigate the relationship between applied force and the speed of the arrow upon release. As the arrow follows a projectile motion trajectory after being released, what physical quantities are affected by changing the launch angle of the bow and arrow? How should the pulling force and launch angle be combined to hit the bullseye? Try to figure out how a weaker archer can hit the target.

Adjustable parameters:

Maximum force: The maximum force that can be applied when pulling the string.

Launch angle: The angle at which the arrow is released from the bow.

Checkboxes:

"Graphs": When checked, displays force(F) versus draw length(dx) of the bow graph, the elastic potential energy(Us) versus time(t) graph, and horizontal kinetic energy(Ek) of the arrow versus time(t) graph of the arrow.

v.abstract: This program simulates a simple model of germ transmission in a confined space
v.desc:
This program simulates a simple model of germ transmission in a confined space. There are 900 dots in the space; red dots represent infected, germ-carrying individuals and blue dots represent healthy individuals. At the beginning of the simulation, the user can set the original number of infected people (num); after the simulation is run, the dots will move around the space, and when the red dots touch the blue dots, the healthy people will be infected, and the blue dots will turn red (become infected). The user can also choose different quarantine policies. The simulation will isolate the number of isolated people set by the user every 5 simulation seconds (not actual seconds, but rather a different unit of time used by this simulation), and then the isolated red dots will disappear from the screen and the number of infected people will be shown next to the green dots on the left. The simulation will stop when all dots become red (all infected) or when the simulation time is > 60.

What do you think will happen to the number of infected people over time without a quarantine policy?

1.     How will the number of infected people change over time?

2.     How do results differ or stay the same when there is a small initial number of infected individuals (e.g., num=3) versus when there is a large initial number of infected individuals (e.g., num=49)?

 

What percentage of infected individuals should be isolated each time to effectively suppress the transmission of the disease (no more than 450 infected individuals can be isolated)?

1.     What are the effects of different isolation percentages?

2.     How does the relationship between the number of infected individuals and time vary?

Simulation parameters:

num: the initial number of infections

Quarantine policies:

·       No quarantine policy: No infected people will be isolated with this option

·       Quarantine 90% of infected: 90% (i.e. 9/10) of infected will be isolated every 5 simulation seconds.

·       Quarantine 75%: 75% (3/4) of the infected population will be isolated every 5 simulation seconds.

·       50% isolation: 50% (i.e. 1/2) of the infected population will be isolated every 5 simulation seconds.

·       25% isolation: 25% (or 1/4) of the infected population will be isolated every 5 simulation seconds.

 

How to operate simulation:

(1)   Set the initial number of infections (num) and select a quarantine policy.

(2)   Click "Run" to start the simulation. To observe the relationship between the number of infections and time, click "Graph" on the right side of the data table.

(3)   When the "All Infected" or "End of Simulation" dialog box pops up, press "X" on the right to close the dialog box.

Press "Reset" to terminate the simulation. You can reset the parameters and press "Run" to start the next simulation.

v.textA: "two pieces of clay with equal weight"
v.desc:
The simulation models the process of two sinking pieces of clay with equal densities and masses but different shapes. Taking two pieces of identical clay, roll one into a solid sphere and the other into a bowl-shaped form. Place the two pieces of clay into cups of water. What happens? The simulation has 2 models:
Mode 1: When the simulation begins, the two pieces of clay are lowered slowly into the water.
Mode 2: The two pieces of clay are placed on a handheld balance. When the simulation begins, they are lowered slowly into the water, and the water displaced by the clay will be collected in tiny buckets to the side.
After observing the simulation, are you able to explain why the two pieces of clay (which have equal densities and masses) have different behaviors after being lowered into the water? Find an actual bucket of water and real pieces of clay and conduct your own experiment! When describing ship sizes, the term “displacement (tonnage)” is often used. Do you know why now?
Instructions:

(1)  Choose “Mode 1” or “Mode 2”
(2)  Click Play to run the simulation. Click Pause to pause and observe changes such as readings on the balance or the height of the water surface.
(3)  Click Reset to end the simulation.
Checkboxes: Show weight/buoyancy (vectors)

v.desc:
The program simulates the induced current in the coil when the magnetic flux across the coil changes. The circuit consists of a metal coil in series with an ammeter. There is also a permanent magnet bar at the right. In the “Drag” mode, you can click on the magnet bar or the coil to drag them. Please observe how factors such as the speed, relative moving direction of the magnet bar and the coil, and the number of coil turns influence the brightness of the light bulb and the strength and direction of the induced current using the ammeter. In the “Magnet bar automated” or the “Coil automated” modes, the magnet bar / the coil automatically moves back and forth in a uniform motion and the moving speed V is adjustable. Again, observe how factors such as the speed, relative moving direction, of the magnet bar and the coil, and the number of coil turns influence the brightness of the light bulb and the strength and direction of the induced current using the ammeter.

Operation modes :
Drag: Click on the magnet bar or the metal coil to drag them horizontally.
Magnet bar automated: Adjust the moving speed and the magnet bar moves back and forth in a uniform motion for observing the relative motion direction of the magnet bar and the coil.
Coil automated: Adjust the moving speed and the coil moves back and forth in a uniform motion for observing the relative motion direction of the magnet bar and the coil.

 V: moving speed

 Buttons:
Flip magnet bar: click to flip the polarity of the permanent magnet bar
Increase/decrease the number of turns: click to increase or decrease the number of coil turns.

Checkboxes:
Induced current direction: click to show the direction of the induced current.
Induced magnetic poles: click to show the induced magnetic poles on the coil.
Right-hand rule: click to show the right-hand rule figure corresponding to the induced current
Magnetic field line: click to show the magnet field of the magnet bar
Light bulb: click to show the light bulb and its brightness
Slow-motion: click to play the simulation in slow motion
Pause animation at a fixed point: click to pause the animation at a particular point for easier observation of the change of the induced current during the process. To continue the simulation, click “play”. (The magnet bar is still in uniform motion, and only the animation is paused )

Instructions:
(1) Set the operational mode
(2)Click the buttons or the check boxes for observing the variations of selected physical quantities
(3)Press "reset" to reset the simulation

v.desc:
This program simulates the kinetic process of a non-elastic collision and the following projectile motion. There is a ghost of mass Ma(kg) on a hill (height=180m)。On the edge of the hill sits a pumpkin。The ghost moves at a velocity of Vxa (m/s) and ends up hitting the pumpkin。 After collision，the ghost sticks to the pumpkin and both fall off the hill (gravitational acceleration g=10 m/s2) 。A skull was placed on the ground 180 meters away from the edge of the hill。The aim of the game is to make the ghost and pumpkin to hit on the skull。
