v.abstract: This program simulates the motion an object being thrown out by a person standing on the rotating table and its trajectories observed form the rotating frame and on the ground(inertial frame).
v.desc:
This program simulates the motion an object being thrown out by a person standing on the rotating table and its trajectories observed form the rotating frame and on the ground(inertial frame). In the simulation, there is a round table roating with a constant angular velocity w. Ash Ketchum stands at the center of the round table while holding a Pokeball, and Pikachu was on the edge of the round table. After the simulation is executed, the user can press the "launch" to make Ash throw the Pokeball out at a constant speed in the aimed direction. Can you figure out whether Ash can make the Pokeball reach and catch the Pikachu by aiming in the direction towards it? Where will the Pokeball reach in the end? Directly in front of Pikachu, forward right to Ash, or forward left to Ash? Will Misty, who stands on the ground, observe the same Pokeball trajectory as Ash, who stands on the round table? Does the Pokeball land at the same point on the edge of the round table? When the rotating table rotates counterclockwise or clockwise, how do the trajectory of the Pokeball and the position of the landing point change? Where should the Pokeball be aimed to successfully retrieve Pikachu?

 Alterable parameters:
Observer’s position: Options: "ground (Inertial frame)" or "On the rotating table"

w: Angular velocity of rotating table (w>0 counterclockwise rotation；w<0 clockwise Rotation)

Aiming direction: options for the aiming direction when the Pokeball is thrown "Pikachu"；"Orange circle"；"Blue circle"

Checkboxes:

Trajectory of every second: Check to show the trajectory of the Pokeball every second after it is thrown

Coordinates: When selected, two sets of coordinates are displayed after the Pokeball is thrown. The black/ gray dotted coordinate axis indicates the ground (inertial coordinate) coordinates; the green coordinate axis is the rotating coordinate axis on the rotating table.

Coriolis force (Fictitious force): Click to show the direction of Coriolis force (Brown arrow), This force will only be displayed when the observer is on the rotating table.

The dotted line indicates the force is an fictitious force. It also aids the explanation of the curve trajectory observed by the observer under the rotating(non-inertial) frame The brown arc is the trajectory of the Pokeball, and it is displayed at the same time as the Coriolis force to help the user observe that the direction of the Coriolis is perpendicular to the tangent direction of the trajectory. The Coriolis force is equivalent to the centripetal force of an uniform circular motion.

Slow motion: When selected, the motion of the Pokeball is played in slow motion after the Pokeball is thrown. 

Button: ----- launch ----- Press this button to launch the Pokeball in the aimed direction.

Simulation instruction:

(1) Press “Play” to execute the simulation

(2) Set the alterable parameters.

The sequence of the above two steps can also be reversed

(3) press "Launch" to throw the Pokeball in the aimed direction

(4) When the Pokeball reaches the edge of the round table, a message pops up, and the simulation will reset after the message is closed.

This program simulates the changes in height of the two liquid columns and pressure in the U-shaped tube when different samples are placed on one side of the tube. The U-shaped tube is filled with a liquid of density D (g/cm3). When both sides of the tube are open to the atmosphere, the pressures exerted on the liquid surface of both sides of the tube are 1 atm (1033.6 gw/cm2). Users can drag pressure gauges (placed in the lower-left corner) to a position in the liquid and measure the pressure. Do you know what factors affect the pressure at this spot? How does the pressure change when the liquid density in the tube changes?
When one side of the tube is connected to a sample that exerts pressure to the liquid and the other side remains open, the heights of the two liquid columns change due to the pressure difference between the two sides of the tube. Do you know how the pressure difference determines the height difference on both sides? Please drag the object (bulb A filled with unknown gas and pressure, bulb B filled with unknown gas and pressure, object 12.5kg, and object 25kg) and place it on one side of the tube to exert pressure. Observe the difference in height on both sides and use pressure gauges to measure pressure in the liquid.

Alterable variables:
D: liquid of the fluid in the tube(g/cm3)

Draggable object: bulb A filled with unknown gas, bulb B filled with unknown gas, object 12.5kg, object 25kg, 5 pressure gauges (the measured point is at the tip of the red triangle)

Instructions:
(1) Drag a sample to the tube to exert pressure and remove the sample  by dragging it back to the left side.
(2) Drag the pressure gauge to any position to measure the pressure.
(3) Adjust the value of D to change the density of the liquid in the tube.

v.langmode0: "Please compare the differences of wetness of top and the side after both giants have been running for 5s"
v.langmode1: "Please compare the differences of wetness of top and the side after both giants have been running for the same distance"
v.radio-33_text: "run for the same period of time"
v.desc:
This program simulates two giants running in the rain with different speed and calculates how many raindrops will they catch。In the simulation we assume the body volume of the giant as rectangular blocks。The effective volumes of both giants are the same and do not change while they are running。Raindrops fall vertically(no wind) onto the giant with a constant velocity (terminal speed)。The density of the rain shower is assumed to be uniform in space and time。The running speed of giant A (black) is twice faster than the giant B (brown)。
"Will I get wetter if I run in the rain?" is an interesting question to ask。In this simulation, we set two circumstances for the two giants to run in the rain : (1) to run for the same period of time in the rain and (2) to run from eaves m to eaves n (the same distance)。 Can you answer the following questions before/after you run this simulation? 

1. Giant A (faster runner) catches (more / less / the same) amount of raindrops falling on the top than Giant B? Why?
2. Giant A (faster runner) catches (more / less / the same) amount of raindrops falling on the front side than Giant B? Why?
3. Giant A (faster runner) catches (more / less / the same) amount of raindrops falling on the whole body (both on the top and front side) than Giant B? Why?


To run the simulation:
(1) press button to set the circumstances "run for the same period of time"  or "run from eaves m to n"
(2) press "Play" to run the simulation and press "Reset" to terminate
The light blue rectangles shown on the giants represent the amount of raindrops on the top；The blue rectangles shown on the giants represent the amount of raindrops on the front side。

v.desc:
This simulation allows the student to control the depth of a submarine's submersion in water. The submarine has a mass of 300 grams and a volume of 525 cm3 and is floating upon the surface of the water at the start of the simulation (density of water: 1.0 g/cm3). Users can add or remove water from the toy submarine's ballast tank to control the depth of the submarine's submersion and observe changes in the buoyancy of the submarine.

Instructions: Buttons: Add water/Remove water (can be tapped multiple times) Observe the changes in the submarine's motion and net force. Checkboxes: Weight/Buoyancy Check to show weight/buoyancy vectors. Click Pause to compare the magnitudes of weight and buoyancy. Click Play to resume simulation. The table on the right of the simulation displays relevant variables such as mass of submarine and buoyancy.

v.ml_infoTitle: Coriolis force - tossing a ball on a turntable
v.desc:
This program simulates a ball being tossed out on a rotating table with constant rotation speed and the ball’s trajectory being observed in different coordinates. In the simulation, there is a turntable with constant angular velocity “w” with four balls on it(Blue, red, pink, brown). When the simulation is executed, the user can set the launch position of the ball, the angular velocity of the round table, and the position of the observer. Then, press the"launch" button and the four balls will be launched according to their aiming direction(Dotted arrows of the same color)respectively. The user can observe the trajectory of the balls after they are launched with different parameter settings.

Alterable parameters:

Launching position: options "Edge of the turntable" or "Center of turntable"

w: Angular velocity of the turntable (w>0 counterclockwise rotation (Northern Hemisphere)；w<0 clockwise rotation (Southern Hemisphere))

Observer position: option "Ground (Inertial coordinates)" or “Turntable"

button:----- launch -----Press this button to launch the Pokeball in the aimed direction.

Simulation instruction:

(1) Press “Play” to execute the simulation

(2) Adjust the alterable parameters

(3) Press the "Launch" button to launch the four balls in the aimed direction.

(4) 5 seconds after the ball is thrown out, the simulation will automatically pause to help the users observe the position and trajectory of the balls

(5) Press "Reset" to reset the simulation

v.desc:
A cannon fires a ball with mass m kg at a height h km from Earth's surface with a horizontal velocity V (m/hr). According to Newton’s law of universal gravitation, the cannonball is subjected to a gravitational force F=(G∙M∙m)/r2 where M = Earth’s mass (5.972*^1024 Kg), r = distance between the ball to Earth's center (h + 6372 km, assuming Earth’s radius is 6372 km).
Fired at a low velocity, the cannonball does not travel far before it lands. Fired at a higher velocity, the cannonball travels for a longer distance, but eventually falls back down because of gravitational force (as in the case of intercontinental ballistic missiles). Fired at a high enough velocity, the cannonball falls into orbit around the Earth and does not fall back to the ground (as in the case of satellites). If this orbit is circular, then the centripetal force on the cannonball is equal to the gravitational force on the cannonball, as in

 m∙V2/r = (G∙M∙m)/r2

If you were to fire a cannon from the top of Mount Everest (h = 9 km), what would be the minimum velocity for the cannonball to fall into orbit around Earth instead of landing back on the ground? What would be the escape velocity for the cannonball to escape from Earth’s gravitational pull?

Alterable Variables:
h: altitude of the cannon (km)
V: cannonball’s initial linear velocity
Instructions: Set variables h and V. Then Click Play to begin simulation. Click Reset to end simulation.

v.ml_infoTitle: Ohm's Law: Series and Parallel Circuits
v.desc:
This simulation models a circuit with one or two resistors in either series or parallel construction and shows the current and the flow of electrons within the circuit. When there is only one resistor present in the circuit, students can change the voltage and resistance of the circuit to observe Ohm’s Law (V = I*R). When two resistors are present in the circuit, students can select either series or parallel construction of the resistors. Observe the brightness of the lightbulb(s). Click “Ammeter” to show Ohm’s Law equations.

Alterable Variables:
V: battery voltage (V)
R1: resistance of resistor 1 (1kΩ)
R2: resistance of resistor 2 (1kΩ)

Checkboxes:
“Ammeter”: Check to replace lightbulbs with ammeters
“R1 Disconnected”: Check to disconnect R1 from the circuit

Single-Choice Options: " Current "; " Electrons "
Choose whether to show electric current or flow of electrons

Instructions:

(1)   With only one resistor present in the circuit, change the battery voltage and resistance and observe Ohm’s Law (V = I*R).
(2)   Choose either series or parallel construction of two resistors. Change battery voltage and resistance and observe changes in electric current.
(3)   Click Reset to return to circuit with only one resistor.

Notes: The depiction of electron flow in this simulation is aimed at elementary and middle school students. For high school and above, a closer and more accurate depiction of electron flow is available in this PhET simulation: https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/legacy/battery-resistor-circuit

v.desc:
﻿This simulation explores refraction and Snell’s Law as light passes through a flat boundary between two different media. In the simulation, light passes from a medium with a low refractive index (n1) to a medium with a high refractive index (n2) at a level boundary surface.
“The Fastest Route”: In this mode, assume that light moves through medium n1 with speed v1, and through medium n2 with speed v2; v2 = n1*v1/n2. Four paths are shown in the simulation (gray, red, blue, purple), on each of which is a circle moving at the speeds prescribed above from point A to point B. Which circle will reach point B first? How does changing n2 change the fastest route? What kind of relationship exists between the angle of incidence and the angle of refraction?
“Snell’s Law”: In this mode, the student can drag the red circle using a mouse to change the angle of incidence as well as change the refractive index n2 of the second medium.

Alterable Variables:
Buttons (Modes): “The Fastest Route”; “Snell’s Law”
n2: refractive index of the second medium
Checkboxes: Protractor (check to show protractor)

Instructions:

(1)   Choose a mode: “The Faster Route” or “Snell’s Law.”
(2)   Set n2 and click Play to run simulation. Click Reset to end simulation.

Display:The gray, red, blue, and purple arrows represent the speeds of the gray, red, blue, and purple balls, respectively.

v.abstract: A boat not subject to any outside forces carries Mario. This simulation models the motions of Mario and the boat after Mario stars to run at a constant speed.
v.desc:
A boat not subject to any outside forces carries Mario. Assume that there is no friction between the water surface and the boat and that Mario moves at velocity V toward the back of the boat. Mario’s initial position is at x = 0 and he weighs 50 kg. At a horizontal distance D meters from Mario (x = D) there is a treasure cloud in the sky. The boat weighs Mb kg and is 2000 cm long (center of mass at x = 0). When Mario reaches the edge of the boat, he will be launched up by a spring. Can you set the variables so that Mario reaches the treasure cloud when he jumps? (Acceptable margin of error: ±15 cm from the arrow on the cloud)

Alterable variables:
Mb: boat mass (kg)
V: Mario’s velocity (cm/s)
D: horizontal distance between Mario’s initial position and the treasure cloud (cm) 

Instructions:

Set variables (Mb, V, D) to desired values and click Play to begin the simulation. Click Reset to end the simulation.

Display:
Orange dots: position of Mario's center of mass after each second
Black dots: position of the boat’s center of mass after each second
Pink dot: center of mass of the system
Blue arrow: Mario’s velocity
Brown arrow: boat’s velocity

The simulation uses a simple temperature-atmospheric pressure model to simulate the cause and variation of land and sea breezes.
v.desc:
The simulation uses a simple temperature-atmospheric pressure model to simulate the cause and variation of land and sea breezes. Users can control the land surface temperature by clicking on the pink triangle on the thermometer at the land surface and selecting the observation checkbox to observe the variations in atmospheric pressure and wind direction at that temperature. The cruise ship offshore indicates the direction and the strength of the wind with the smoke coming out of its chimney. The land surface temperature is Tland, the sea surface temperature is Tsea, and the temperature difference between sea and land is Tdiff=Tland-Tsea。 In the simulation, only when the temperature difference between the sea and land is greater than 6℃ and the horizontal pressure difference between the sea and land surface is greater than 12 hPa will a medium scale (few km to tens of km) land-ocean wind field be formed. 

Observation checkboxes:

Barometer: select to show the barometer. The user can click and drag the barometer to measure the pressure at a different location.

Height markings: select the display height reference line

Wind field diagram: select to show the diagram of the wind field. The arrows will only be displayed when the land and sea winds are formed, and the size of the arrow indicates the strength of the wind speed. The arrows are presented in a dynamic manner, indicating the order and moving direction of the air pack when the wind field is formed. The color of the arrow represents the change in temperature when the air pack moves. Red indicates hot and blue indicates cold.

Isobaric line: select to the display isobaric line of the air pressure

v.desc:
This simulation models the behavior of a projectile as it leaves a slingshot. A person first applies a force F to the slingshot and pulls it back a length of dx, then releases it so that the projectile leaves the slingshot with an initial velocity Vx parallel to the ground and eventually lands at a distance from the person. In this simulation the person initially uses a blue slingshot with elastic constant k. The distance traveled by the projectile using this slingshot is marked by the black oval on the ground. There are two other slingshots: one with elastic constant ka < k (brown) and the other with elastic constant kb > k (purple). Assuming that either the amount of force applied to the slingshot or the maximum length to which the slingshots stretch is fixed--which slingshot should the person choose in each situation so that the projectile hits the Angry Bird on the ground?

Imagine yourself to be the person using the slingshot, and you can only exert force up to a fixed maximum. Which slingshot

should you pick so that the projectile travels the farthest?

If you had infinite strength, but the rules of a competition state that the slingshot can only be stretched to a fixed maximum length, which slingshot should you pick so that the projectile travels the farthest?

Instructions:

  1. Choose a scenario: “fixed amount of force” or “fixed length of stretch.”

  2. Click Play to run the simulation. Observe the slingshot and the projectile. Click OK on the dialog box that pops up to confirm that the simulation has ended.

  3. Choose a scenario: “fixed amount of force” or “fixed length of stretch.”

  4. Drag the slingshot you would like to test (brown or purple) to the person’s hands to replace the original blue slingshot.

  5. Click Play to run the simulation and see if you have completed the objective (hit the Angry Bird).

Check “Hide |F|-|dx| and Ek-t Graphs” to hide the graphs in the simulation screen.

A reindeer pulls at a sled with a force of 24 N. A present with mass Ma is placed on the sled. There is friction between the present and the sled, with coefficient uab.

(2) When Ma = 1, what is the minimum value of uab so that the present does not slide off? (3)  When the mass of the present increases, is it more difficult for the present to slide off?
Can you figure out the general relationship between Ma and uab so that the reindeer can safely deliver the present to Santa?

v.ml_infoTitle: free fall-which will hit the ground first?
v.desc:
This is a simulation of 4 objects with different forms and masses free falling from a height H = 90 meters, either in air or in vacuum. At the left, the red sphere and the blue cube have the same mass (500 grams) and are made of the same material (same density). On the right side are a toy parachute carrying a 200-gram object and a feather that weighs 50 grams. When an object falls in air (no turbulence), it experiences the downward force of gravity Fg = -m*g and the upward force of air resistance FD. The amount of air resistance experienced by an object depends upon its form, surface area, and mass. In general, FD can be calculated as:

FD = 0.5*CD*ρ*A*v2 = k*v2         (CD: drag coefficient，ρ: air density，A: cross sectional area)

The CD of the objects in this simulation are:

Red sphere: 0.5

Blue cube: 1.05

Parachute: 1.42

Feather: 2

The motion of the objects can be modeled by:

F = m*a = Fg + FD= -m*g + k*v2

m*(dv/dt) =-m*g+ k*v2

(dv/dt) = -g + k*v2/ m

When the force of gravity is equal to the force of air resistance, the falling velocity of an object becomes constant. This velocity is called the terminal velocity.

Within a vacuum, the only force acting on all 4 objects is gravity. According to Newton’s Second Law, the acceleration of a falling object is a fixed value (gravitational acceleration g= 9.8 m/s2).

F=m * dv/dt = m*a = -m*g

dv/dt = -g

As such, the 4 objects will land at the same time within a vacuum.

Alterable Variables:

Ma:mass of the red sphere (grams)

Button: “Vacuum”: The default setting of the simulation models the falling of objects in air. To observe objects falling in vacuum, click this button.

Instructions: (1) Choose either air or vacuum and decide whether to show vectors, velocity, and/or second-by-second trace. (2) Click Play to run the simulation.

Green arrow: force of gravity Blue arrow: normal force Yellow arrow: force of air resistance Purple arrow: velocity Dots: position of object each second

Objects in Free Fall Experiment (Air vs Vacuum): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E43-CfukEgs&t=58s

A giant runs at velocity V in the rain from underneath roof m to roof n. His velocity (V) and the density of the rainfall (rho) can be changed.
v.desc:
A giant runs at velocity V in the rain from underneath roof m to roof n (distance D = 24 m). Assume that the effective volume of the giant is a rectangular block, the density of the rainfall (rho) is uniform, raindrops fall vertically (no wind), rain falls at terminal velocity u = 6 m/s, and that the giant runs slower than the rain (V ≤ u).
Should you run in the rain? How much rain will you “catch” if you do? The simulation calculates the amount of rain that falls on the giant’s head, on his sides, and in total (head + sides) as he runs. What happens to these 3 values when the giants runs at different velocities?

1. How does the amount of rain that falls on the giant’s head change when he runs faster? (Increase/No change/Decrease) Why?
2. How does the amount of rain that falls on the giant’s sides change when he runs faster? (Increase/No change/Decrease) Why?
3. How does the amount of rain that falls on the giant in total change when he runs faster? (Increase/No change/Decrease) Why?

Alterable Variables:
V: running velocity (m/s)
rho: rain density

Instructions: After settings variables to desired values, click Play to run simulation. Click Reset to end simulation.

Display:
As the giant runs, the growing light blue rectangle beginning at the top of his head represents the amount of rain that falls on his head. The growing dark blue rectangle beginning at his side represents the amount of rain that falls on his side(s).

v.abstract: The program simulates a simple model of the spreading behavior of viruses in a closed space.
v.desc:
The program simulates a simple model of the spreading behavior of viruses in a closed space. In the simulation, there are two sets of spaces (A and B) each containing 900 dots. The red dots represent the ones who are infected by the virus, and the blue dots represent the ones who are healthy. At the beginning of the simulation, you can adjust the number of virus carriers. After the simulation starts, the dots move randomly in the closed space. Once a blue dot is contacted by a red dot, the blue dot turns into a red dot (infected). You can also choose different quarantine policies to employ. The simulation automatically quarantines a fixed portion (depending on the setting) of infected people every 5 units of simulation time. Then, the quarantined red dots disappear from the screen, and the number of quarantined patients will be shown beside the green dot in the top-left corner. The simulation stops when all the dots becomes red (infected) or when the simulation time > 60.  

Under the circumstance of no quarantine policy, try to find the answer to these questions: (1) What is the evolution of the number of infected people over time? (2)What’s the difference in the infected number v.s. time plot when the original number of infected people is different (for instance: 3 compared to 49).

Before employing the quarantine policy, what do you think is the required portion of people to quarantine to suppress the propagation of the viruses effectively (for instance: contain the infected number within 50% of the total number (450 people))? (1) What’s the effect of different quarantine portions? (2) How will the infected number v.s. time plot change accordingly?  

 

Simulation parameters:

Options:

Initial infected number of group A: 3; 9; 27; 45

Quarantined portion of group A: 0%; 25%; 50%; 90%

Initial infected number of group B: 3; 9; 27; 45

Quarantined portion of group B: 0%; 25%; 50%; 90%

(Note:

Quarantine 90% of the total infected people: quarantines 90% (or 9/10) of the infected people every 5 units of simulation time.

Quarantine 75% of the total infected people: quarantines 75% (or 3/4) of the infected people every 5 units of simulation time.

Quarantine 50% of the total infected people: quarantines 50% (or 1/2) of the infected people every 5 units of simulation time.

Quarantine 25% of the total infected people: quarantines 25% (or 1/4) of the infected people every 5 units of simulation time.

Quarantine 0% of the total infected people: quarantines none of the infected people every 5 units of simulation time.)

Instructions:

(1) Set the initial infected number of people and the quarantined portion of the infected.

(2) Press “Play” to start the simulation. To observe the infected number v.s. time plot, click “Plot” beside the data table.

(3) When the message “All infected” or “Simulation finished” pops up, please click “x” at the top-right corner to close the message.

(4) Press “Reset” to end the simulation or reset the parameters and press “Play” to start the next simulation.

This simulation models the superposition of two traveling waves with the same wavelength (la) and period (T). When the two waves are traveling in opposite directions (green wave to the right, red wave to the left), a standing wave is formed. When the two waves are traveling in the same direction (both to the right), the result is another traveling wave. The simulation allows the student to change the wavelength (la), period (T), view mode, velocity distribution of the waves (Vy), and the direction(s) in which the waves travel.


Button: View Modes

Mode1 shows initially the two travelling waves and the resultant wave as a result of their superposition

Mode2 presents all the waves in a single, overlapping format that shows how the forms of the two traveling waves and the resultant wave change with time.

Checkboxes:

View Vy: Show/Hide the velocity distribution of the waves

Direction: Change the direction of the red wave (left/right)

Slow Motion: Change the play speed of the simulation (normal/0.5x), used for making observations about the change in the distribution of velocity on the resultant standing wave (when the difference between the phases of the two waves is 180 degrees, the standing wave appears to form a straight line with amplitude = 0, but the velocity at different parts of the wave are not 0)

The program simulates the motion of transverse wave (top) and longitudinal wave (bottom). The arrows indicate the velocity of vibration of the five points (A, B, C, D, E). |AB|=Wavelength/4；|AC|= Wavelength/2；|AD|= Wavelength *(3/4)；|AE|= Wavelength

Checkboxes:

Pause every quarter period: The simulation plays continuously when the option isn’t selected. When selected, the simulation pauses automatically every quarter period for easier observation of the positions and velocities of point A~E. After the pause, click the “Play” button at the top-left corner to continue the simulation.

Instructions:

(1)   Press “Play” to start the simulation.

(2)   Press “Pause” at appropriate timing for easier observation of the variations of the phase, the position of peaks and troughs, and the velocity at different points.

(3)   Press “Play” to continue the simulation.

Press “Reset” to end the simulation.

v.ml_infoTitle: Frictional and centripetal forces- Radius of rounding a curve
v.desc:
This simulation models the motion of a car traveling on a round curve at different speeds and the wheels of the car rolling normally without slipping and sliding. Users can choose a road surface on which the car travels and the car speed, run the simulation to explore the relationship between the car speed and the radius of the car’s circular path while it rounds a curve without slipping or sliding on the road. Then, you can use the knowledge you have learned in previous practice to accomplish the mission of parking. Click “Mission” and set the traveling speed to successfully make the car pass through the yellow gate.

Types of road:
Frictionless road: the friction coefficient between the tyres and road is 0.0.
Wet grass: the friction coefficient between the tyres and grass is 0.4.
Dry asphalt: the friction coefficient between the tyres and asphalt road is 0.8. 

Alterable variable:
V: Car speed (km/hr)

Checkboxes:
“Centripetal force”: show a red vector that represents the centripetal force on the car.
“Mission”: show the settings and conditions of the mission.

Instruction:
(1) Set a type of road and car speed.
(2) Click “Play” to run the simulation. While running, you can click “Pause” to pause the simulation.
(3) Click “Reset” to end the simulation.

v.ml_infoTitle: Centripetal Force – Path and Period of Satellites
v.desc:
This simulation models the motion of a satellite as it orbits Earth. Since the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1 in 1957, thousands of satellites have been launched and are now orbiting Earth. These satellites have different functions, and the radii and the periods of their orbits differ accordingly. Earth’s gravitational pull supplies the centripetal force necessary to keep these satellites in orbit. This centripetal force points toward the center of the Earth.

m*r*w2=(G*M*m)/r2


m: mass of the satellite

M: mass of Earth (5.972*1024 kg)

r: radius of satellite orbit

w: angular velocity of satellite


Assume that the radius of Earth is 6372 km. There is a satellite signal reception station on Earth's surface located on the equator (red block). At a height h km above the Earth's surface is a satellite that orbits in the same direction as the direction of Earth's revolution.


(1) When a satellite has an angular velocity equal to that of Earth's revolution, it is called a geosynchronous. Can you set h so that the satellite remains directly above the ground station as it orbits (assume each revolution of Earth takes 24 hours)? What is its linear velocity


(2) Students can also observe how distance from the ground relates to the angular velocity with which the satellite orbits Earth. Can you determine whether a non-geosynchronous satellite is located higher or lower than a geosynchronous satellite by noting the direction in which it passes through the the sky as observed from the ground station (west to east or east to west)? (Hint: The distance between Earth and the moon is 384400 km, and the period of the moon is approximately 27 days. How does the moon orbit?)

Alterable variables:

h: distance from the ground to the satellite (km)

Instructions: (1) Set variable h to a desired value (2) click "Play" to run the simulation (3) click "Reset" to end the simulation

v.abstract: A cube with density rhoC floats in a liquid with density rhoA. The faucet slowly adds a liquid B with density rhoB. What happens to the cube when liquid B is gradually added?
v.desc:
The simulation models the behavior of a cube with density rhoC = 0.5 (g/cm3) floating in a liquid (with density rhoA) as a faucet gradually adds a liquid B (with density rhoB). The cube’s density is fixed at 0.5 g/cm3, with side lengths of 10 cm and mass 500 g. The depth of the added liquid B is 6 cm. The following relationship exists among the densities of the cube and liquids: rhoA > rhoB > rhoC.
Before adding liquid B, the yellow line on the cube marks the surface of liquid A. After adding liquid B, will the yellow line be above, below, or at the level of the liquid surface? Changing the densities of the liquids, sometimes the submerged portion of the cube is in both liquid A and liquid B, and sometimes it is only in liquid B. What factors affect this? What if rhoA and rhoB are set equal to each other (for example, both set to 1)?
PS: The simulation does not show the way the cube and the surface of the liquid(s) rock/sway when liquid B is added, focusing only on the forces of buoyancy and gravity in the y direction.


Alterable Variables:
rhoA: density of liquid A (g/cm3)
rhoB: density of liquid B (g/cm3)

Instructions:
After setting variables to desired values, click Play to begin simulation. Click Reset to end simulation.

v.desc:
This program simulates the trajectory left on on the moving paper tape of a the ticker-tape timer with a set time interval. In the simulation, the user can set the mode of operating the paper tape:

In the situation selection mode, please set the situation setting below. The simulation changes based on the selected situation (Stationary/Slow and steady/Fast and steady/Slow to fast/Fast to slow) and move the paper tape.

In the manual dragging mode, the user needs to use the mouse to drag the hand icon to let the paper tape move towards the right side.  Users can also select the plotting option to observe the x-t plot, v-t plot, and a-t plot of the process.

Operation mode selection buttons:

Situation selection mode: Under this mode, please set the situation settings below. The paper tape moves and is dotted in the selected motion situation.

Manual dragging mode: In this mode, please set the alterable parameters (td) and then press the "Play" button to execute the simulation. Then, use the mouse to click to drag the hand icon to move the paper tape.

Alterable parameters:

td: Dotting time interval(s)

Situation selection buttons: Click to set the situation setting so that the paper tape is automatically pulled.

Stationary: V=0 cm/s

Slow and steady: V=2.5cm/s Move slowly in a uniform motion.

Fast and steady: V=5 cm/s Moves fast in a uniform motion.

Slow to fast: Initial velocity is 2 cm/s, acceleration= 1 cm/s2 with uniform acceleration.

Fast and slow: The initial speed is 10 cm/s, acceleration=-2cm/s with uniform deceleration motion.

Plotting options:

none: No plotting

d-t plot: Displays x-t plot after selecting the option.

v-t plot: Display v-t plot after selecting the option. If the operation mode setting is "Situation selection mode", when td=1, the message “Simulation finished” pops up. After that, a scissor icon appears on top of the paper tape. By clicking on the scissor icon, you can cut the section of the paper tape. Release the mouse and the section of the paper tape will be transferred to the V-t plot. You can see that the paper tape can fill up the area below the v-t plot = total length of the paper tape = the displacement of the tape.

a-t plot: Click to show the a-t plot

Checkboxes:

Data: click to show the data

Ruler: Click to show a blue ruler. You can move it to the desired location by dragging it using the mouse

Coordinates: Click to hide the x-axis coordinate

Pause after each dot: Click to pause the simulation after each dot is made. To resume the simulation, press the “Play” button in the upper-left corner

v.desc:
The program simulates the induced current in the coil when the magnetic flux across the coil changes. The circuit consists of a metal coil in series with an ammeter. There is also a permanent magnet bar at the right. In the “Drag” mode, you can click on the magnet bar or the coil to drag them. Please observe how factors such as the speed, relative moving direction of the magnet bar and the coil, and the number of coil turns influence the brightness of the light bulb and the strength and direction of the induced current using the ammeter. In the “Magnet bar automated” or the “Coil automated” modes, the magnet bar / the coil automatically moves back and forth in a uniform motion and the moving speed V is adjustable. Again, observe how factors such as the speed, relative moving direction, of the magnet bar and the coil, and the number of coil turns influence the brightness of the light bulb and the strength and direction of the induced current using the ammeter.

Operation modes :
Drag: Click on the magnet bar or the metal coil to drag them horizontally.
Magnet bar automated: Adjust the moving speed and the magnet bar moves back and forth in a uniform motion for observing the relative motion direction of the magnet bar and the coil.
Coil automated: Adjust the moving speed and the coil moves back and forth in a uniform motion for observing the relative motion direction of the magnet bar and the coil.

 V: moving speed

 Buttons:
Flip magnet bar: click to flip the polarity of the permanent magnet bar
Increase/decrease the number of turns: click to increase or decrease the number of coil turns.

Checkboxes:
Induced current direction: click to show the direction of the induced current.
Induced magnetic poles: click to show the induced magnetic poles on the coil.
Right-hand rule: click to show the right-hand rule figure corresponding to the induced current
Magnetic field line: click to show the magnet field of the magnet bar
Light bulb: click to show the light bulb and its brightness
Slow-motion: click to play the simulation in slow motion
Pause animation at a fixed point: click to pause the animation at a particular point for easier observation of the change of the induced current during the process. To continue the simulation, click “play”. (The magnet bar is still in uniform motion, and only the animation is paused )

Instructions:
(1) Set the operational mode
(2)Click the buttons or the check boxes for observing the variations of selected physical quantities
(3)Press "reset" to reset the simulation

v.langmode0: "The blue ball lands 0.1 second earlier than the red ball"
v.langmode1: "Both objects land at the same time"
v.langmode: "Both objects land at the same time"
v.desc:
This program simulates the motions of two objects free falling from the height。The philosophers of sixteen century believed that the falling speed of the object is proportional to the mass of the object，such as an iron ball falls faster than a feather。But Galileo proposed a logical inference to against this theory。He compared the falling speeds of two objects with different weights when they fall individually to been tied together and pointed out the contradictions among them。Therefore he suggested that the falling speed of object should be independent of its mass 。All  free falling objects are driven by the same acceleration so that they will all fall with the same speed when they fall from the same height。 It is widely told that Galileo had done an experiment from the leaning tower of Pisa by dropping two balls made with the same material but different by weight。He observed that both balls hit the ground almost at the same time to prove his theory。However，historians find no documents to support this story and account it as a "thought experiment" 。Nevertheless，Galileo's theory of free-falling bodies sets the foundation of Newton's laws of motions developed a century later。
When we drop two objects with different mass from the same height on the earth，the falling speed and time they take to hit the ground could be different due to the presence of air resistance。This dragging force depends the shape，mass and cross sectional area of the objects。When Apollo 15 landed on the Moon on 1971，astronauts  carried out the famous "hammer and feather experiment" to prove Galileo's theory of free-fall。
The equation of motion for a free falling object is :

F =  Fg + FD = -m*g + k*v2

(k: coefficient of air resistance) 
m*(dv/dt) = -m*g + k*v2

dv/dt = -g + k*v2/m

On the Earth: k>0，g=10 m/s^2
On the Moon: k=0，g=1.666 m/s^2

To run the simulation:
(1) choose a scene: on the Earth / on the Moon 
(2) press "Play" to run the simulation，press "Reset" to terminate
arrows shown in the simulation: speeds of the objects
dots shown in the simulation: trajectories of the objects every second

Related links:
free-fall experiment on the Earth: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E43-CfukEgs&t=58s
free fall experiment on the Moon:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5C5_dOEyAfk

v.us_comment: "static friction coefficient between the slope and the cube"
v.desc:
Experiment of friction on the inclined plane is the original experiment that Leonardo da Vinci (1452–1519) had done to study the nature of frictional forces。By tilting the angle of the slope up over a critical degree，the cube would slide down the incline itself without exerting any external force to the cube。For the cube，the normal force (Fn) is the component of its gravitational force perpendicular to the inclined plane。The sliding force (Fg) comes from the component of its gravitational force parallel to the inclined plane。When the slope angle is tiled over a certain degree, the sliding force becomes larger than the static friction force ( Fsmax=Fn*us)；it results in the sliding of the cube。In this simulation，students can study

(a)changes of Fn，Fs，Fg when you adjust the slope angle(c)
(b)the relationsips between frictional coefficient (us) and slope angle(c) when the cube starts to slide down。

Alterable parameter:
c: angle of slope (degree)
M: mass of the cube (kg)
us: static friction coefficient between the slope and cube

To run the simualation:
(1) set your parameters (M，us)，press “Play” to run the simulation
(2) adjust angle of slope (c) till the cube starts to slid down the slope
(3) press “Reset” to terminate the simulation

checkbox: tick to show the force diagram

Data:
c: angle of slope (degree)
M: mass of the cube (kg)
us: static friction coefficient between the slope and cube
Fn: normal force of the cube (Newton)

v.desc:
This program simulates the pressure change at different locations inside the container when the water level changes. In the simulation, two connected containers hold liquids of density D (g/cm^3). On the connecting pipe between the two containers is a brown water valve that controls the opening and closing of the pipe. In the upper-left corner of the screen is a faucet to add more liquid. The pressure gauge (maximum number of 6) in the upper right corner can be dragged to different locations to help the user to measure the pressure at different points in the container. The user can control the liquid density, add more water, open and close the water valve, and use the pressure gauge at different positions to see the cause of pressure changes at each point in the container and see how to calculate the pressure at that point.

Adjustable parameters:

D: Liquid density

Button "Add water": After pressing the button, water flows out of the faucet every two seconds. When the water is added multiple times, and the water level in the container is close to the top, no more liquid can be added.

Two-state button "Open the water valve/Close the water valve": Press this button repeatedly to control the opening and closing of the water valve.

Check box "Subtract atmospheric pressure": The box is selected by default. At this point, the atmospheric pressure is automatically subtracted when the pressure gauge measures the pressure, which is convenient for users to experiment and calculate the pressure at different points in the container; when the box is not selected, the reading of the pressure gauge includes the atmospheric pressure (Patm=1033.6 gw/cm2).

Checkbox "Measure point": Select to show the reference point for the measurement. This function is made for the convenience of the teachers in class to help organize the students' measurements in the classroom; when the box isn't selected, the reference measurement point will not be displayed.

Instructions:

Adjust the parameters, set the buttons and boxes, and drag the pressure gauge to the position you want to measure. Please experiment with the pressure changes at different points in the container and try to calculate the pressure at that point. To reset the simulation, please press the "Reset" button.

v.desc:
This program simulates the relationship between the applied force and the buoyancy experienced by a volleyball (with a diameter of 20.175cm and a weight of 300g) as it is pushed into a liquid. In the simulation, users can set the density of the liquid, drag the hand icon on the screen to control its position to push the volleyball into the liquid. Observe the relationship between the applied force of the hand, the weight of the volleyball, the volume of the volleyball submerged in the liquid, and the buoyancy experienced by the volleyball. Users can also conduct real experiments using a bucket and a ball to experience the feeling of applying force to push the ball into water, and explore the concept of buoyancy with the data displayed on the simulation.

Adjustable parameters:

Ds: liquid density (g/cm^3)

Checkboxes:

Weight: Check to display the gravitational force acting on the volleyball

Buoyancy: Check to display the buoyancy experienced by the volleyball

Applied force: Check to display the force applied from the hand

Simulation instructions:

(1) After setting the parameters, drag the hand icon with the mouse to control its position to push the volleyball into the liquid.

(2) Press the "Reset" button to terminate the simulation.

v.desc:
This program simulates the motion of a pendulum. In the simulation, there is a ball pendulum with mass m(g), the swing angle is c(degree), and the coefficient of friction between the string and the axle is r. The user can choose the location of the experiment, adjust the parameters, and observe the changes in the mechanical energy of the pendulum when it swings.

Adjustable parameters:

c: Swing angle(degree)

m: Pendulum mass(g)

r: Coefficient of friction between string and axle

V0: Initial velocity of pendulum(cm/s)

Check box:

Pendulum velocity: Select to show pendulum velocity (red arrow).

Mechanical energy: Select show mechanical energy.

Slow motion: Select to play the animation in slow motion.

Pausing at fixed-point: After selection, the simulation will pause once when the single pendulum swings reach the closest point to the maximum pendulum angle. (note: Since the time resolution during simulation is 0.02 seconds when the pause message pops up, the current pendulum will be very close to the position of the half-cycle, but sometimes it may not be exactly equal to the point of the half-cycle. For example, if the parameter you set is the initial swing angle=20o, the half of the pendulum period is about 1.268 s. However, due to the limitations of the simulation time resolution, the simulation can only return its position at 1.28 seconds and pause the simulation at that time. )

Instructions:

(1) After setting the adjustable parameters, press “Play” to execute the simulation

(2) Press “Pause” to pause the simulation. Using the function with the timer in the simulation, the user can record the time it takes for the pendulum to swing a fixed number of times to calculate the period of the pendulum.

      The "Plotting" page simultaneously displays the change of the mechanical energy/potential energy/kinetic energy of the pendulum over time.

(3) To end the simulation, please press “Reset”. You can reset the parameters and press “Play” to perform the next simulation.

v.slider-2_format: "Velocity of the duck/Velocity of the water wave"
v.abstract: This program simulates a duck paddling on the lake and the water ripples it causes when it moves at different speeds
v.desc:
This program simulates a duck paddling on the lake and the water ripples it causes when it moves at different speeds. The purpose of the simulation is to investigate how the relative velocity between point source of wave and the propagation of water wave affects the pattern of the water ripples. Have you ever observed what the ripple looked like when a duck swims across the lake? How to know whether the duck is swimming fast or slow only by looking at the waves beside the duck? In the simulation, a duck is moving in a uniform motion to the right. The duck slaps the water surface with its feet every second, causing the water wave to travel outward at the speed of the water wave. What happens to the ripples we observe when the duck moves slower or faster than the water waves travel?

Alterable parameters:
Vratio: Velocity of the duck/Velocity of the water wave (The ratio of the two velocities)

Checkboxes:
Velocity of the duck: Indicate the velocity of the duck moving.
Velocity of the water wave: Indicate the propagating velocity of the water ripples produced by the duck’s feet paddling

v.langmode0: "simulation paused! To end simulation, please click Reset button"
v.ml_infoTitle: String wave-amplitude, frequency, and wave velocity
v.desc:
The program simulates the string wave generated by swinging a long string. You can adjust the amplitude and the frequency with which the string is swung to observe the difference in the resulting waveform. You can also change the thickness of the string (the material stays the same) to observe the difference in the resulting velocity. The blue arrow on the screen, traveling to the right as the string swings, indicates the traveling direction of the string wave. In addition, you can also observe the motion of the bow knot (point P) on the string. By clicking “position vs. time plot of point p”, the variation in position versus time plot of point p is shown in the bottom half of the simulation.

 Button:
Thick string: Change the string to a thick string
Thin string: Change the string to a thin string 

Alterable parameters:
A: Swinging amplitude (cm)
f: Swinging frequency of the hand (s-1) 

Pausing modes:
“Pause every period”: The simulation pauses automatically after the string swings a single period. To move on to the next period, press “Play” in the upper-left corner to continue the simulation.
“Pause every quarter period”: The simulation pauses automatically after the string swings quarter period. To move on to the next period, press “Play” in the upper-left corner to continue the simulation.
“Pause after the wave propagates for 600 cm”: After the wave (the blue arrow) propagates for 600 cm, the simulation automatically pauses. To continue the simulation, press “Play” in the upper-left corner.

Checkboxes:
“position vs. time plot of point p”: Click to show the variation of position versus time plot of point P (bow knot).
“Slow motion”: Click to play the simulation in slow motion. 

Instructions:

(1) Set the thickness of the string, alterable parameters, and checkboxes.

(2) Click “Play” to start the simulation. To pause the simulation, click the “Pause” button.

(3)If the “Pause every period” mode is selected, please use it in unison with the “Play/Pause” button for easier observation or easier data recording at the desired location.

(4) When the “Slow motion” mode is chosen, please use it in unison with the “Play/Pause” button to stop the simulation at positions that are easier to observe and record data (such as the position of point P in the y-axis and time).

(5)When the “Pause after the wave propagates for 600 cm” mode is chosen, you can observe the time and the position of the blue arrow in the data columns to obtain its velocity. To resume the simulation, press the “Play” button.

(6)Press the “reset” button to end the simulation.

v.desc:
This simulation models images formed by refraction when an object (red and arrow-shaped) is placed in front of a thin concave lens. In the simulation, three principal rays in the ray diagram are: (1) A ray traveling parallel to the optical axis refracts through the concave lens and its extension will pass through a focal point on the object’s side. (2) A ray passing through the center of the lens is undeviated. (3) A ray which travels on the way to the focal point behind the lens refracts through the thin convex lens and then travels parallel to the optical axis. Users can drag around the arrow-shaped object to observe changes in size, orientation, and location of the image formed by refraction. In the simulation, a real image is represented by a red arrow drawn as a solid line. A virtual image is represented by a red arrow drawn as a dashed line.

Instruction:
(1) Set the focal length f of the thin concave lens
(2) Drag around the red arrow-shaped object in front of the lens to observe the image. You can drag the eye around and place it in front of or behind the lens to check if the image can be observed by the eye. 

Alterable variable f: Focal length
Multiple choice: (a) None (b) Static ray diagram (c) Dynamic ray diagram

v.desc:
The program simulates the spinning motion of a simple electric motor that operates based on the magnetic field produced by current. In the simulation, a conducting solenoid is placed between two permanent magnets with opposite polarity. The solenoid is a copper wire coil wound on top of an iron core. Two ends of the wire coil are attached to the two metal half-circles on the central spindle. The two metal half-circles are in contact with wires on both sides, and the wires are connected to the battery below. When all the wires form a closed circuit, the current flows into the coil and produces a magnetic field, magnetizing the iron core and making it an electromagnet. The motor turns due to the magnetic forces between the electromagnet and the permanent magnets, converting electrical energy into mechanical energy.

Alterable variables:
V: Voltage of the battery

Button: Increase/decrease the number of turns on the coil

Checkboxes:
Parts: click to show name of parts
Current direction: Click to see the direction of the electric current in the circuit.
Coil polarity: Click to see the polarity of the electromagnet when the coil is conducting.
Right-hand rule: Click to reveal the direction of magnetic field produced by the coil via the right-hand rule 
Slow-motion: Click to see the simulation played at a slower speed.

Instructions:
(1)   After setting the battery voltage, press “Play” to start the simulation.
(2)   Press “Pause” to pause the simulation for descriptions and easier observations.
(3)   Click the button or the checkboxes to show the descriptions.
(4)   Press “Reset” to end and reset the simulation.

v.us_comment: "coefficient of static friction between the ramp and the people"
v.abstract: Two objects with different masses slide down a ramp. Which will slide down first?
v.desc:
In this simulation, two objects with different masses slide down a ramp (an angled surface). The coefficient of friction between each of the two objects (Santa/Elf) and the ramp surface is µs. When the ramp angle increases past a certain value, the force of friction becomes less than the force of gravity, and the object(s) begins to slide downward. Assume that the angle at which the Santa will begin to slide is c1, and that for the Elf is c2. Do you think that the Santa will begin to slide first (c1 < c2), the Elf will begin to slide first (c1 > c2), or they will begin to slide at the same time (c1 = c2)? What factors affect the angle at which an object begins to slide down the ramp? After the Santa and the Elf begin to slide down, which moves with a greater velocity? Which moves with a greater acceleration? Does setting the coefficient of friction to 0 reveal anything interesting?

Notes:

(1)  The National Taiwan Science Education Center in Shilin, Taipei has a slide in its Physics Games Area. Wear pants of the same material, and remember to keep your legs straight (so that the soles of your feet are not touching the surface of the slide).
(2)  The friction ramp experiment was one of the experiments used by Leonardo da Vinci (1452–1519), who conducted the first systematic study of friction, to investigate the nature of friction. This experiment assumes no outside force to explore how changes in the ramp angle affect the force of friction.
µs: coefficient of (static) friction between the ramp and the object(s)
c: ramp angle
Instructions:
(1)  Set µs to desired value and click Play to begin simulation.
(2)  Increase c to make the ramp steeper until objects begin to slide down
(3)  Click Reset to end simulation.
Display:
Black arrow: velocity of objects while sliding down the ramps
ta/tb: time taken for each object to reach the bottom of the ramp after it begins to slide

This simulation models the image formation by thin convex lens and ray diagrams
v.desc:
This simulation models the image formation by thin convex lens and ray diagrams. In the simulation, users can choose one of three different situations of image formation, set the focal length f of the thin convex lens, and choose the type of ray diagrams. In the simulation, three principle rays in the ray diagram are : (1) A ray traveling parallel to the optical axis of the lens refracts through the lens and then passes through the focal point on the other side of the lens; (2) A ray passing through the center of the lens is undeviated; (3) A ray passing through the focal point on the way to the lens refracts through the lens, and then travels parallel to the optical axis. Users can drag around the arrow-shaped object placed to the left of a thin convex lens to observe changes in size, orientation, and location of the image formed by refraction. In the simulation, a real image is represented by a red arrow drawn as a solid line. A virtual image is represented by a red arrow drawn as a dashed line.

Situations of image formation:

“Parallel light rays”: The incident rays are all parallel to the optical axis of the lens (sunlight for example). After rays refract through the lens, they all pass through the focal point behind the lens. On the screen, there is a draggable matchstick. Drag the matchstick to light it at the focal point.

“An arrow-shaped object”: On the screen, there is a draggable arrow-shaped object. Drag the object to a desired position and observe how the three principle rays determine the location of the image. The eye shown on the screen is also draggable. Drag the eye around to judge whether the image is real or virtual.

“Applications of convex lens”: On the screen, there are three optical instruments “Camera”, “Projector”, and “Magnifying glass”. Click one of them to observe the ray diagrams, the location of the object, and its image when the instrument is used.

Alterable variable:
f: focal length

Multiple choice:

(a)   None (b) Static ray diagram (c) Dynamic ray diagram

Zoom in: Click “Zoom in” to magnify the field of view

Zoom out: Click “Zoom out” to reduce the field of view 

Instruction:

(1) Choose the situation of image formation and set the focal length of the thin convex lens.

(2) Drag around the red-arrow-shaped object placed to the left of the convex lens to observe its image.

(3) Choose the type of ray diagram.

v.abstract: 此程式模擬物體受外力施力後的運動過程。
v.desc:
此程式模擬物體受外力施力後的運動過程。聖誕節到了，聖誕老公公要準備去送禮物了，聖誕老公公可以在雪橇上放多少禮物? 又應該用幾隻麋鹿來拉雪橇呢? 模擬中使用者可以控制拉動雪橇時麋鹿的拉力，也可以拖曳畫面左方的聖誕老公公與禮物，將他們放置到雪橇上，完成設定後執行模擬，觀察麋鹿拉力與雪橇上的載重如何影響雪橇的運動速度。在麋鹿拉雪橇奔跑後，也可以按"鬆開韁繩"鈕讓麋鹿跑開，不再對雪橇施以拉力，來觀察移除外力後雪橇的運動。如果雪橇與地面的摩擦力不同時，雪橇的運動又會有甚麼不同呢?
模擬操作:
(1)設定雪橇與地面的摩擦力，麋鹿的拉力與雪橇上的載重

(3)按"重置"鈕結束模擬

v.abstract: 此程式模擬強酸與強鹼滴定的過程
v.ml_infoTitle: 酸鹼中和-強酸強鹼(教學)
v.desc:
此程式模擬強酸(鹽酸)與強鹼(氫氧化鈉)滴定的過程。模擬中使用者可以設定錐形瓶中與滴定管中的溶液，所要使用的酸鹼指示劑和每次加入滴定的容量；並可以搭配勾選顯示滴定數據，作圖或是粒子觀點示意圖，然後點擊滴定管上的閥門開始進行滴定，並且觀察滴定過程中溶液pH值的變化與各種離子定性上數量地變化。


模擬操作:
(1) 設定錐形瓶與滴定管中的溶液類型
(2) 選定酸鹼指示劑的類型 
(3) 逐次點擊滴定管的開關閥，每次點擊會定量加入所指定的滴定液容量(0.05 ~10毫升)。(如果於步驟(2)時選擇的是酚酞，酚酞於高濃度鹼性溶液裡的變色範圍為 8.2<pH<12 (https://highscope.ch.ntu.edu.tw/wordpress/?p=4870%22)。
(4) 滴定過程中可以搭配勾選顯示滴定數據，作圖或是粒子觀點示意圖來觀察滴定過程中溶液pH值的變化與各種離子定性上數量地變化。
(5) 完成滴定後，請按"重置"鈕終止模擬
備註:
(1)當勾選"作圖"時，圖表右方會出現"趨勢線"勾選框，勾選趨勢線時會顯示滴定全程pH值隨滴定體積的變化趨勢線(趨近於理論值的擬合線)
(2)當勾選"粒子觀點示意圖"時，由於模擬目的在於示意滴定過程中粒子數目比例的變化，在此模式下，滴定液容量的設定只有5和10 毫升的設定。

感謝新北市海山高中國中部胡心如老師，永和國中陳敏華老師，竹圍高中國中部林緯豈老師參與模擬設計

v.abstract: 此程式模擬一不受外力的作用的船上載著馬力歐，當馬力歐以等速 V 由離岸邊較遠的船緣向另一邊移動時，馬力歐與船的運動。
v.desc:
此程式模擬一不受外力的作用的船上載著馬力歐，假設船與水面間無磨擦力，當馬力歐以等速 V 由離岸邊較遠的船緣向另一邊移動時，馬力歐與船的運動。 船一開始停在岸邊，離岸邊 D 公尺的天空有ㄧ片寶藏雲。馬力歐重 50 公斤，船身重Mb公斤，船身全長為 20 公尺。當馬力歐移動至船緣時會踩到彈簧向上跳。你知道要如何調控參數，讓馬力歐向上跳時恰巧撞上寶藏雲(允許誤差範圍: 雲上箭頭所指處 ± 0.15公尺)得到金幣嗎?
可調參數:
Mb: 船重 (公斤)
V: 馬力歐的移動速度(公尺/秒)
d: 寶藏雲離岸邊的距離 (公尺)
模擬操作: 設定好參數 (Mb, V, D) 後按Play 執行模擬，按Reset 結束模擬。
顯示說明:
橘色圓點: 馬力歐每間個一秒的位置
黑色圓點: 船每間隔一秒的位置
綠色圓點: 系統質心位置
藍色箭頭: 馬力歐的移動速度
棕色箭頭: 船的移動速度
粉紅色線段: 船身全長 20 公尺
數據欄:
t: 時間
Mb: 船重 (公斤)
V: 馬力歐的移動速度 (公尺/秒)
D: 寶藏雲離岸邊距離 (公尺)
Xa: 馬力歐的質心位置 (公尺)
Xb: 船的質心位置 (公尺)
Xc: 系統的質心位置 (公尺)
相關模擬聯結: http://cosci.tw/run/?name=Fv0yrk1462772445401

v.abstract: 此程式模擬二維完全彈性碰撞條件下兩球的運動。
v.desc:
完全彈性碰撞-二維 此程式模擬二維完全彈性碰撞條件下兩球的運動。碰撞前，紅球以 Va=100 公分/秒的初速前進，碰撞靜止(Vb=0公分/秒)的綠球，兩球間的夾角為c1(度，相對X軸)；碰撞後，紅球以c2(度)的角度(相對於x軸)彈開。
可調參數:
Ma: 紅球質量 (公克)
Mb: 綠球質量 (公克)
c1: 兩球碰撞前夾角 (度) (此值為負值是因座標選擇設定)
模擬操作: 設定好參數後，按Play執行模擬。結束模擬請按Reset。可重新調整參數，再按Play執行模擬。
顯示欄參數:
Ma:紅球質量 (公克)
Mb:綠球質量 (公克)
Va:紅球速度 (公分/秒)
Vb:綠球速度 (公分/秒)
c1:碰撞前兩球間夾角 (度)
c2:碰撞後紅球角度 (度)

v.abstract: 此程式模擬波的形成。
v.desc:
此程式模擬波的形成。 橫波: 模擬畫面中的左邊紅點會周期性的上下振動，其右方的藍點以每間隔 dx 的距離排列，且每個藍點以時間延遲 delay 後開始與紅點一樣的周期性上下振動，沿著右方藍點傳遞這樣的振動行為後便成了橫波波動，波動傳遞方向(+X)與介質運動的方向(±Y)相垂直。這個波動傳遞的速度為 v=dx/delay。 縱波: 模擬畫面中的左邊紅線會周期性的左右振動，其右方的藍線以每間隔 dx 的距離排列，且每個藍線以時間延遲 delay 後間開始與紅線一樣的周期性左右振動，沿著右方藍線傳遞這樣的振動行為後便成了疏密波波動，波動傳遞方向(+X)與介質運動的方向(±X)相平行。這個波動傳遞的速度為 v=dx/delay。(備註:為了使疏密波看起來更清楚，當調整參數時，線的左右移動振福也會相對應調整。)
可調參數:
delay: 藍點移動延遲時間(s)
dx: 藍點的間距
模擬操作:
(1) 按 "橫波" 或 "縱波" 按鈕選定摸的模式
(2) 設定好參數(delay，dx)後按 Play 執行模擬，按 Reset 終止模擬。
模擬顯示:
紫色箭頭: 波的傳遞方向(速度)
綠色箭頭: 介質的運動方向(速度)
模擬參考:師大黃福坤教授: 物理問題討論區 http://www.phy.ntnu.edu.tw/demolab/phpBB/viewtopic.php?topic=26496

https://www.iconfinder.com/icons/3253/hand_share_icon#size=128

v.abstract: 此程式模擬不同的樣品，在固定熱源下加熱升溫，熱源移除後降溫的過程。
v.desc:
此程式模擬不同的樣品，在固定熱源下加熱升溫，熱源移除後降溫的過程。模擬中的酒精燈提供固定的加熱源，以300卡/分鐘(Q=300)加熱樣品，樣品從室溫(25℃)開始被加熱，持續加熱 heat_t 分鐘後，酒精燈會被移除(Q=0)，然後降溫10分鐘後模擬結束。加熱過程中樣品的溫度(T)與其溫度的變化(dT)遵守下列關係:
dT=T-T0   (T0=25℃室溫)
d(dT)/dt=(Q*eff-C*dT)/(m*S) .............(一)
式子(一)右方第一項 Q*eff 熱源存在時，熱源加熱樣品使溫度上升
Q: 熱源加熱速率  加熱熱量H=Q*t
eff: 熱源熱量有效傳導至加熱樣本係數，在此為 (0.9*(1/50)*t)，剛開始加熱時有約10%熱被器具而非樣品本身吸收
式子(一)右方第二項為樣品溫度與室溫間的溫度差造成的熱耗散
C: 熱傳導相關係數
m: 樣品質量
S:樣品比熱

模擬中五個樣品的比熱分別為: 水: 1.0 卡/(公克*℃)    鋁塊: 0.22 卡/(公克*℃)    甘油: 0.58 卡/(公克*℃)    沙子: 0.2 卡/(公克*℃)
使用者可挑選兩不同樣品分別置放在兩加熱架上，比較兩樣品兩歷經相同加熱與降溫條件下溫度的變化。老師可引導學生挑選樣品，設計實驗，觀察比較兩樣品溫度變化的差異，介紹比熱的定義，並比較出樣品間比熱的大小順序為何。

可調參數:
heat_t: 加熱時間(分)
單選選項(實驗模式):
"只加熱": 實驗模式只顯示加熱到設定的加熱時間 heat_t 後就停止
"加熱與降溫": 實驗模式為先將樣品加熱heat_t 分鐘後移除熱源，然後降熱10分鐘
模擬操作:
(1)設定加熱時間與實驗模式
(2)用點選拖曳模擬上方的兩個樣品至加熱架A B 上
(3)按 "Play" 執行模擬；按 "Pause" 暫停模擬(觀察或記錄數據)；按 "Reset" 重置模擬

模擬顯示:
紫色虛線: 樣品的初始溫度(室溫)
紅色虛線: 樣品加熱至heat_t 分時的溫度
藍色虛線: 樣品降溫10分鐘後的溫度

the icons used in this simulation were downloaded from:
https://www.flaticon.com/free-icon/burner_223751

v.abstract: 此程式模擬強酸與強鹼滴定的過程
v.ml_infoTitle: 酸鹼中和-強酸強鹼(基礎)
v.desc:

(3) 逐次點擊滴定管的開關閥，每次點擊會定量加入所指定的滴定液容量(0.05 ~10毫升)。(如果於步驟(2)時選擇的是酚酞，酚酞於高濃度鹼性溶液裡的變色範圍為 8.2<pH<12 (https://highscope.ch.ntu.edu.tw/wordpress/?p=4870%22)。

v.abstract: 此程式模擬物體放置在不同材質的路面上受拉力時，拉力與物體所受摩擦力的變化
v.desc:
此程式模擬物體放置在不同材質的路面上受拉力時，拉力與物體所受摩擦力的變化。模擬中有一台牽引車拖著一個藍色長方形物體，使用者可以設定不同的路面類型來控制路面與牽引車和重物的摩擦係數，也可以設定重物的質量與擺放的方式，然後增加牽引車的拉力，來觀察物體的在多少拉力下會開始移動。當物體開始移動後，如果切斷拉繩，物體的運動會有甚麼變化呢?
模擬操作:
(1)設定路面類型，物體質量與擺放方式
(2)按"增加拉力"按鈕，每次會增加5 牛頓的拉力，觀察並記錄物體在多少拉力時會被拉動
(3)按"重置"鈕終止模擬

感謝彰化市彰德國中洪銘謙參與模擬設計與討論

教育雲上摩擦力探究的教學影片:https://video.cloud.edu.tw/video/co_video_content.php?p=402186

v.abstract: 此程式模擬戰鬥機執行投彈任務時，炸彈的運動軌跡。
v.desc:
此程式模擬戰鬥機執行投彈任務時，炸彈的運動軌跡。戰鬥機以速度V(公尺/秒) 向正X方向飛行，飛行一秒後，每間隔一秒的時間釋放一顆炸彈，連續釋放六顆炸彈，程式模擬三種不同的起始條件:
(1) 飛機等速水平飛行: 飛機以水平速度Vx (公尺/秒) 飛行(Vy=0)，在觀察模擬結果前，試問學生 (a) 於飛機飛行第六秒時，飛機與六顆子彈間其Y方向的位置分佈應為何? 此分佈由哪個物理量決定? (b) 當所有炸彈都落地後，每顆炸彈的落點分佈為何? 由哪個物理量決定?
(2) 飛機等速向下俯衝: 飛機飛機以水平速度Vx (公尺/秒)，垂直速度 -Vy(公尺/秒)，向下俯衝，試觀察炸彈的運動軌跡與落點，與飛機等速水平飛行的狀況有何同，異之處呢? 請加以討論。
(3) 飛機等速向上拉升: 飛機飛機以水平速度Vx (公尺/秒)，垂直速度 Vy (公尺/秒)，向上拉升，試觀察炸彈的運動軌跡與落點，與飛機等速水平飛行的狀況有何同，異之處呢? 請加以討論。
模擬操作:
(1) 按鈕選定飛行模式: "飛機等速平飛"，"飛機等速俯衝"，"飛機等速拉升"
(2) 按 Play 執行模擬，按 Reset 終止模擬。
the icon used in this simulation was downloaded from: https://icons8.com/web-app/4982/prop-plane#filled

v.abstract: 此程式模擬光線射入平面鏡後反射的光路
v.desc:
此程式模擬光線射入平面鏡後反射的光路。這是一個要將雷射光透過平面鏡反射後射入模擬右上方粉紅色圓球處的計時遊戲任務，當雷射光射中粉紅色圓球處時畫面中會顯示你所使用的秒數並出現跳舞的Elmo，請你跳出Elmo的舞步讓同伴們知道你完成任務。模擬中左上角有六面平面鏡(白色)，使用者可以用滑鼠按壓並拖曳平面鏡到模擬畫面中想放置的位置，用滑鼠點擊雷射/面鏡，並設定左上角的變數拉桿"角度"的數值來控制雷射/面鏡的角度，好讓雷射光射種右上角的粉紅圓球。模擬中的紅色面鏡位置與角度是固定的，無法被調整。試試看你需要用到幾面鏡子與發費多少時間才能完成任務!

感謝宜蘭縣宜蘭國中吳宛如老師參與設計模擬與討論


http://gifgifs.com/animations/creatures-cartoons/cartoon-characters/Elmo_shakes_it.gif

v.abstract: 此程式模擬一單擺運動。
v.desc:
此程式模擬一單擺運動。模擬中有一個質量為 m(公克) 的圓球擺錘，擺線的長度為 L(公分)，擺角為 c(度)，擺線與固定軸間的摩擦係數為 r。使用者可選擇實驗地點，調整上述參數，觀察擺的周期與這些參數間的關係，擺動時力學能的變化。
可調參數:
地點: 地球(g=980 公分/秒平方)；月球(g=163.3 公分/秒平方)
c: 擺角(度)
L: 擺長(公分)
m: 擺錘質量(公克)
r: 擺線與固定軸間的摩擦係數
單選方框:
慢動作: 勾選以慢動作撥放動畫
擺錘速度: 勾選顯示擺錘速度(紅色箭頭)
五個週期計時: 勾選後模擬會在單擺擺動五個週期時暫停，讀取碼表數值除以五，可得到單擺的週期
作圖單選按鈕:
無: 畫面中無作圖顯示
擺角-時間圖: 畫面右方顯示擺角-時間圖(上)與角速度-時間圖
力學能長條圖: 以長條圖顯示動能，位能與力學能的變化
力學能-時間圖: 畫面右方顯示力學能-時間圖
執行模擬:
(1) 設定可調參數後按 Play 執行模擬
(2) 按 Pause 可暫停模擬，搭配模擬畫面中的碼錶，使用者可紀錄固定擺動次數的時間來計算擺的周期
(3) 結束模擬請按 Reset，可重新設定參數後按 Play 執行下一次模擬。

在十六世紀前計時器多以水力或重錘轉動齒輪的機械式時鐘，其體積龐大且精準度不佳，通常只能到準確到數十分鐘。伽利略因觀察到比薩教堂裡因風搖晃的吊燈的擺動，設計了單擺實驗，藉由改變擺的長度，擺垂重量等因子歸納出擺的擺動周期與這幾個因子間的關係。單擺的往復擺動是最早觀察到物理的簡諧運動的實例，單擺穩定的周期性提供了精準的計時方式，伽利略於晚年被囚禁時(西元1637年)與兒子共同設計了以單擺為調節驅力的擺鐘，可惜那時他年事已高並來不及將它完成，而是於西元1656年，荷蘭科學家海更斯Christiaan Huygens 設計完成第一個以秒計時的擺鐘。爾後，製作擺鐘的技術不斷進步，西元1720後，英國鐘表匠哈里森 John Harrison 製作的擺鐘一個月的時間誤差才1秒，且至今仍正常擺動計時。哈里森更利用彈簧設計可在船上使用的航海時鐘，準確的計時讓航海家得以計算出船隻航行時所處的經度，避免船難讓長距離的海上航行更安全，進而將世界推入大航海時代與其後的國際貿易。而於科學上，精準的計時是推動科學實驗的基石，描述物體運動，觀察天體的運行都需要準確的計時才得以讓科學家們歸納出物理定律。

v.abstract: 此程式模擬色光的疊加
v.desc:
此程式模擬色光的疊加，模擬中有代表光的三原色(紅，綠，藍)的圓，當使用者按壓拖曳其中一個圓(色光)並移至另一個圓(色光)上時，模擬會顯出色光疊加的結果。當使用者將滑鼠點選在畫面中任一處，畫面右上角會顯示該處的色碼。使用者也可以設定圓的顏色，請用滑鼠點選任一個圓後，更改模擬上方R(紅)，G(綠)，B(藍)色碼的數值，便可以設定該圓的顏色。

the icons used in this simulation were downloaded from:
<a href="https://www.flaticon.com/free-icons/torch" title="torch icons">Torch icons created by Good Ware - Flaticon</a>
https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/4020/4020387.png

v.abstract: 此程式模擬一單擺運動。
v.desc:
此程式模擬單擺運動。模擬中有兩個獨立的單擺，一個為藍色的參考擺，擺長固定為100公分，初始擺角為10度，擺錘質量是200公克；另一個擺是一個質量為 m(公克) 的黑色擺錘，擺線的長度為 L(公分)，擺角為 c(度)，擺線與固定軸間的摩擦係數為 r。使用者可選擇實驗地點，調整上述參數，觀察比較兩個擺的運動與週期，擺動時力學能的變化。
可調參數:
地點: 地球(g=980 公分/秒平方)；月球(g=163.3 公分/秒平方)
c: 擺角(度)
L: 擺長(公分)(當擺長設為0時，畫面中只有藍色參考擺)
m: 擺錘質量(公克)
r: 擺線與固定軸間的摩擦係數
單選方框:
參考擺: 勾選顯示藍色參考擺(若只想觀察黑色擺的運動，請將此項設為"不勾選")
慢動作: 勾選以慢動作撥放動畫
擺錘速度: 勾選顯示擺錘速度(紅色箭頭)
五個週期計時: 勾選後模擬會在黑色單擺擺動五個週期時暫停，讀取碼表數值除以五，可得到黑色單擺的週期 (若黑色單擺的質量m設為0 時，此計時時間為藍色參考擺的擺動時間)
作圖單選按鈕:
無: 畫面中無作圖顯示
擺角-時間圖: 畫面右方顯示擺角-時間圖(上)與角速度-時間圖
力學能長條圖: 以長條圖顯示黑色擺的動能，位能與力學能的變化(若黑色單擺的質量m設為0 時，此顯示為藍色參考擺的力學能變化)
力學能-時間圖: 畫面右方顯示黑色擺的力學能-時間圖(若黑色單擺的質量m設為0 時，此顯示為藍色參考擺的力學能變化)
執行模擬:
(1) 設定可調參數後按 Play 執行模擬
(2) 按 Pause 可暫停模擬，搭配模擬畫面中的碼錶，使用者可紀錄固定擺動次數的時間來計算擺的周期
(3) 結束模擬請按 Reset，可重新設定參數後按 Play 執行下一次模擬。
感謝新北市永和國中陳敏華老師與海山高中胡心如老師參與討論設計模擬。

在十六世紀前計時器多以水力或重錘轉動齒輪的機械式時鐘，其體積龐大且精準度不佳，通常只能到準確到數十分鐘。伽利略因觀察到比薩教堂裡因風搖晃的吊燈的擺動，設計了單擺實驗，藉由改變擺的長度，擺垂重量等因子歸納出擺的擺動周期與這幾個因子間的關係。單擺的往復擺動是最早觀察到物理的簡諧運動的實例，單擺穩定的周期性提供了精準的計時方式，伽利略於晚年被囚禁時(西元1637年)與兒子共同設計了以單擺為調節驅力的擺鐘，可惜那時他年事已高並來不及將它完成，而是於西元1656年，荷蘭科學家海更斯Christiaan Huygens 設計完成第一個以秒計時的擺鐘。爾後，製作擺鐘的技術不斷進步，西元1720後，英國鐘表匠哈里森 John Harrison 製作的擺鐘一個月的時間誤差才1秒，且至今仍正常擺動計時。哈里森更利用彈簧設計可在船上使用的航海時鐘，準確的計時讓航海家得以計算出船隻航行時所處的經度，避免船難讓長距離的海上航行更安全，進而將世界推入大航海時代與其後的國際貿易。而於科學上，精準的計時是推動科學實驗的基石，描述物體運動，觀察天體的運行都需要準確的計時才得以讓科學家們歸納出物理定律。

v.ml_infoTitle: 物體加入液體後的溫度變化
v.desc:
不同溫度的物體接觸時，高溫的物體會放熱降溫、低溫的物體則會吸熱升溫，最終達到相同的溫度。

模擬操作:

(1)選擇燒杯中初始的水溫與水量

(2)選擇加入物體的初始溫度、質量與比熱

(3)選擇加入的物體是液體或金屬塊

(3)按執行鈕即可觀察兩種物體的溫度隨時間的變化

v.ml_infoTitle: 由不同角度觀察直線波前
v.desc:
將波動上相鄰的同相位的點連接即稱為波前，一般較常選擇相鄰波峰或是波谷的連線作為波前。 波前與波的傳遞方向垂直。

模擬操作:

(1)選擇水波的振幅

(2)選擇水波的頻率

(3)按執行鈕即可產生水波

(4)執行前或執行中皆可改變觀看角度

v.abstract: 此程式模擬不同型態的導體，在外加電壓下，量測流經該導體的電流與元件兩端的電壓，來探討導體的電阻變化與類型
v.desc:
此程式模擬不同型態的導體，在外加電壓下，量測流經該導體的電流與導體兩端的電壓，來探討導體的電阻變化與類型。使用者可以設定導體樣品，當設定為碳膜電阻時，可選擇三個不同電阻值的碳膜電阻進行電流與電壓的量測；若樣品設定為發光二極體(LED)，則可以選擇紅光或綠光LED作為量測對象，由於一般的LED的操作電流較低，使用時會串接一個220 歐姆來限制迴路中的電流。
模擬設定:
單選按鈕:
導體類型: "碳膜電阻" 或 "發光二極體(LED)"
勾選方框:
電流電壓圖: 勾選後顯示導體元件的電流電壓圖
電子流: 勾選後顯示迴路中電子流的示意速度與方向
電子元件符號: 勾選後顯示迴路中元件的電子元件符號
模擬操作:
(1) 設定導體樣品
(2) 請使用滑鼠拖曳模擬畫面左方的電池放置到迴路中，逐次增加電池數(外加電壓)並記錄導體元件兩端的電壓與電流，以探究元件的電流與電壓關係與電阻變化。
(3) 完成紀錄後請按"重置"鈕終止模擬。

感謝新北市海山高中胡心如老師參與模擬設計討論

v.abstract: 此程式模擬物體浸入液體的過程中浮力的變化，並透過比較不同的模式設定來探究影響浮力的因素。
v.desc:
此程式模擬物體浸入液體的過程中浮力的變化，並透過比較不同的實驗設定來探究影響浮力的因素。使用者可以設定五個比較模式:
(1)物體沒入液體的體積: 兩個相同的物體，分別沒入相同密度的液體中一半與全部的體積
(2)物體在液體裡的深度: 兩個相同的物體，分別沉入相同密度的液體中深度5公分與10公分處
(3)液體的密度: 兩個相同的物體沉入密度分別為1 公克/立方公分 與 2 公克/立方公分的液體中
(4)物體形狀不同，體積相同: 兩個形狀不同但體積相同的物體，分別沉入相同密度的液體中。(A的截面積為100平方公分，高度為10 公分；B的截面積為200平方公分，高度為5公分)
(5)物體體積不同，形狀相同: 兩個體積不同的物體，分別沉入相同密度的液體中。(A的體積為1000立方公分，C的體積為1728立方公分)
(A，B，C 三個物體的密度皆為2.7 公克/立方公分)
模擬操作:
(1) 設定比較模式與勾選方框以顯示數值
(2) 按"執行"鈕執行模擬
(3) 按"重置"鈕終止模擬

感謝新北海山國中胡心如老師與永和國中陳敏華老師參與設計模擬。
the icons used in this simulation were download from:
https://www.iconfinder.com/icons/1608372/hand_o_rock_icon#size=64
https://www.iconfinder.com/icons/329391/finger_gesture_hand_one_icon#size=128

v.abstract: 此程式模擬不同顏色的球在不同色光照射下所顯現的的顏色
v.desc:
此程式模擬不同顏色的球在不同色光照射下所顯現的的顏色。模擬畫畫面下方有五顆不同顏色的球，其上方有一盞燈，燈的顏色由燈右方的三個開關鈕來控制紅/綠/藍三色色光。點擊單一開關鈕時該色光就會被開啟，再次點擊此開關鈕則該色光會被關閉，如果同時點擊開啟兩個以上的開關鈕，燈光的顏色則為開啟色光的疊加顏色(如開啟紅/綠兩個鈕時，色光為黃色，若是開啟紅/綠/藍三個鈕時，色光的顏色為白色)。請試看看開啟不同的燈光來照射這五顆球，根據你在該色光下觀察到球的顏色，來判斷這五顆球原本是甚麼顏色!
模擬操作:
(1)設定關卡
(2)點擊開關鈕設定燈光的色光
(3)觀察五顆球在色光下顯現的顏色，並判斷五顆球原本的顏色

五顆球的顏色(由左至右):
關卡一:白 藍 紅 綠 黑
關卡二: 黃 紅 洋紅 藍 綠
關卡三: 黃 黑 洋紅 白 青

感謝台中市西苑高中洪菁穗老師參與模擬設計

模擬參考: 王建忍老師 光對顏色的影響 http://edson.tw/chap04/color/primary_t.htm

v.mu_comment: "牆面與方塊間的靜摩擦係數"
v.abstract: 此程式模擬一靠在鉛直牆面上的方塊，方塊質量為Ma公斤，牆面與方塊的靜摩擦係數為mu，請問若不讓方塊落下，最小推力與摩擦力的關係如何?
v.desc:
摩擦力-A 此程式模擬一靠在鉛直牆面上的方塊，方塊質量為Ma公斤，牆面與方塊的靜摩擦係數為mu，動摩擦係數為0.4，同學可於垂直牆面對方塊施以推力F (牛頓)，，試問假若 mu=0.7，要使方塊不滑落時的最小推力為何? 若改變方塊質量或牆面與方塊的靜摩擦係數 mu，最小推力與摩擦力變化如何? (g=9.8公尺/秒^2)
可調參數:
F: 對方塊的推力 (牛頓)
Ma: 方塊質量 (公斤)
mu: 牆面與方塊間的靜摩擦係數
模擬操作: 設定好參數(F，Ma，mu) 後按 Play 執行模擬，觀察完方塊是否滑落後按 Reset 停止模擬，可重新輸入新參數再按 Play 執行下一次模擬。 若要觀看方塊的力圖，請按 顯示方塊的力圖
數據顯示欄:
F: 對方塊的推力 (牛頓)
Ma: 方塊質量 (公斤)
mu: 牆面與方塊間的靜摩擦係數
Fg: 方塊所受重力 (牛頓)
Ff: 方塊與牆面的摩擦力 (牛頓)
(當牆面與方塊間摩擦力不足時，Ff=F*0.4(動摩擦力)；當牆面與方塊間摩擦力足夠時，Ff=Fg)
the icon used in this simulation was downloaded from: https://www.iconfinder.com/icons/3253/hand_share_icon#size=128

v.abstract: 此程式模擬一不受外力的作用的靜止的船上載著馬力歐，假設船與水面間無摩擦力，當馬力歐以等速 V 向船尾移動時，馬力歐與船的運動。
v.desc:
此程式模擬一不受外力的作用的靜止的船上載著馬力歐，假設船與水面間無摩擦力，當馬力歐以等速 V 向船尾移動時，馬力歐與船的運動。假設馬力歐一開始的位置x=0，馬力歐重 50 公斤，距離馬力歐 D 公尺遠的上空有ㄧ片寶藏雲 (x=D)。船身重Mb公斤，船身全長為 2000 公分(質點位置 x=0)。當馬力歐移動至船緣時會踩到彈簧向上跳。你知道要如何調控參數，讓馬力歐向上跳時恰巧撞上寶藏雲(允許誤差範圍: 雲上箭頭所指處 ± 15公分)得到金幣嗎?
可調參數:
Mb: 船重 (公斤)
V: 馬力歐的移動速度(公分/秒)
d: 寶藏雲離馬力歐起點的距離 (公分)
模擬操作: 設定好參數 (Mb, V, D) 後按Play 執行模擬，按Reset 結束模擬。

顯示說明:
橘色圓點: 馬力歐每間個一秒的質點位置
黑色圓點: 船每間隔一秒的質點位置
桃紅色圓點: 系統質心位置藍色箭頭: 馬力歐的移動速度
棕色箭頭: 船的移動速度
數據欄:
t: 時間Mb: 船重 (公斤)
V: 馬力歐的移動速度 (公分/秒)
D: 寶藏雲離馬力歐起點的距離 (公分)
相關模擬聯結: http://cosci.tw/run/?name=Fv0yrk1462772445401
http://cosci.tw/run/?name=7zsftw1479866044375

將物體放置於水平磅秤上時，磅秤上顯示的是物體與磅秤間的正向力(視重)。當物體加速度為0時正向力會與物體的實際重量(實重)相等，但當物體加速度不為0時，正向力與物體的重量將不相等。利用本模擬可觀察物體的視重與加速度方向及量值間的關係。

*本模擬中的大樓高度為450公尺，電梯運行的前150公尺作加速運動，中間150公尺作等速運動，最後150公尺則為減速運動。加速與減速過程的加速度量值相等，僅方向不同。

*若以預設加速度2m/s2運行，費時約需30秒，較目前主流高速電梯(費時約需40秒)稍快一些


模擬操作:
(1)選擇電梯運行的方向
(2)調整電梯的加速度量值
(3)按執行鈕即可啟動電梯
(4)利用方框選擇是否顯示視重、實重、加速度

v.abstract: 此程式模擬不同的色光照射在物品上時眼睛所觀察到的顏色
v.desc:
此程式模擬不同的色光照射在物品上時眼睛所觀察到的顏色。模擬左上方有紅/綠/藍三原色色燈與白色色燈，當使用者點擊色燈開關鈕時就可以開啟色燈，再次點擊該開關鈕就會關閉色燈。當開啟紅/綠/藍三原色色燈時就無法開啟白色色燈，若要開啟白色色燈，請先關閉紅/綠/藍三原色色燈。而模擬中正上方有五個物品的圖示，點擊圖示來選擇放置在模擬下方燈光處的物品。在設定好色光顏色與物品後，便可以觀察到在該色光下模擬右方觀察者眼睛所觀察到物品的顏色。比較看看在圖示中物品原本的顏色與觀察者所看到的顏色是一致的或是不同的呢? 為什麼? 請搭配示意光路來了解原因吧!
模擬操作:
(1) 點擊物品設定放置在燈光下的物品
(2) 點擊色光開關鈕設定色光的顏色
(3) 紀錄模擬中觀察者所觀察到物品的顏色與圖示中物品原本顏色的異/同
(4) 搭配勾選光路示意圖來探究原因

v.abstract: 此程式模擬地球表面的海水因受月球與太陽引力的影響所造成的潮汐現象
v.desc:
此程式模擬地球表面的海水因受月球與太陽引力的影響所造成的潮汐現象。海水漲落的主因來自於地表各處的海水因受到月球與太陽的引力不同所造成的。模擬中分為兩個模式來進行探究，分別為地月模式與日地月模式。模擬畫面右方為從太空觀察地，月，日的位置，而模擬畫面左方則是在地表的小女孩所觀察到海水的漲落。

地月模式: 此模式中探討只有月球一個天體所造成地球上的潮汐現象。地表不同處的海水，由於與月球的距離不同，各處所受到的萬有引力不同，靠近月球一端的海水所受的萬有引力較強，而遠離月球另一端的海水所受的萬有引力較弱(可勾選畫面右上角的萬有引力來觀察各處海水所受月球引力的分布)，又由於地球與月球是一組繞著兩星質心互繞的雙星系統，在地心處地球繞著系統質心的向心力也為萬有引力(粉紅色箭頭)，潮汐力(引潮力)則是地表各處海水所受的月球的引力與在地心處的所受萬有引力(地月互繞的向心力)的引力差(紅色箭頭減去粉紅色箭頭)，使得靠近月球與遠離月球端的海水被拉伸(地月質心連線)，而垂直地月質心連線的兩端海水被朝地心擠壓，海水形成橢圓形的分布(請勾選畫面右上角的潮汐力來觀察其分布)。由於地球自轉一圈（一天）需24小時，而月球繞行地球公轉一圈約為29天，因此當日的第一次滿潮時間會較前一日的第一次滿潮時間慢約50分鐘。

地月日模式:此模式探討月球與太陽的引力共同造成地球上的潮汐現象。與月球的引力相似，太陽對於地表的海水也會造成潮汐現象，雖然太陽的質量比月球大許多，但地球與太陽之間的距離較月球與地球的距離遠很多，因此太陽所造成的潮汐力約為月球的0.45倍，模擬中以灰色橢圓代表月球造成的海水分布，以橘色橢圓代表太陽造成的海水分布。海水的潮高會隨著觀察者，月亮與太陽間的相對位置而變化。


模擬操作:
(1) 設定模式與月亮的位置
(2) 按"執行"鈕執行模擬，可勾選控制滿潮暫停/乾潮暫停的方框，進行觀察與紀錄
(3) 按"重置"鈕終止模擬

ps: 模擬中為了凸顯海水受不均勻的引力影響所形成橢圓形的分布，以及地月日能同時顯示在畫面中，因此畫面中海水的厚度，地月日間的距離並不是依正確天體的比例來畫置
感謝宜蘭縣凱旋國中何中楷老師參與模擬設計

v.abstract: 本程式模擬一斜面上的滑車裝載一小球，滑車初始以初速受重力於斜面上滑下，過程中彈出一小球，小球會再回到滑車上嗎?
v.desc:
本程式模擬一斜面上的滑車裝載一小球，滑車初始以30公尺/秒的初速受重力於斜面上滑下，滑車上的小球於滑行1秒後以30公尺/秒的速度垂直斜面彈出，假設小球彈出時系統內力不變，不影響系統，小球彈出後會再回到滑車上嗎? 如果將斜面夾角值設為零，是否有助於思考呢?
模擬顯示:
綠色箭頭: 小球於沿著斜面的速度(Vsb 公尺/秒)與垂直斜面的速度(Vnb公尺/秒)
紅色箭頭: 滑車沿著斜面的速度(Vsa公尺/秒)
綠色小點: 小球每間隔一秒的軌跡
黑色小點: 滑車每間隔一秒的軌跡
可調參數:
c: 斜面仰角(度)
模擬操作: 選定斜面夾角c值(度)，按Play執行模擬，模擬結束後按Rest後可再重選模擬條件，進行下一次模擬執行。
按鈕:顯示軌跡: 若要顯示滑車與小球每間隔一秒的軌跡，請於設定好參數 c 後按此按鈕，兩物的軌跡將於按 Play 執行模擬時顯示，若於按 Play 後按此按鈕，模擬畫面只顯示按下按鈕後的軌跡。
顯示欄參數:
t: 時間 (秒)
Sa: 滑車沿斜面方向的位移(公尺)
Vsa: 滑車沿斜面方向的速度(公尺/秒)
Vsb: 小球沿斜面方向的速度(公尺/秒)
Vnb:小球垂直斜面方向的速度(公尺/秒)

v.abstract: 此程式模擬物體受外力作用下運動過程為等加速度運動，物體的加速度與外力和物體質量間的關係。
v.desc:
此程式模擬物體受外力作用下運動過程為等加速度運動，物體的加速度與外力和物體質量間的關係。模擬中分為兩種操作模式:
"探究"情境:
模擬畫面上下分別有兩人(A，B)，各自推著一台推車。使用者可以分別設定人施在拖車上的力(FA，FB)與推車的質量(MA，MB)來探究推車運動間的關係。在此模式下，使用可以設定顯示推車的位置，速度，加速度及對應的圖表。此外，當勾選 "A中途停止施力"的選項時，A人將於推動推車三秒後停止施力且放手，來觀察物體的運動於受力時與停止受力後的變化。

"任務"情境:
此模式下分成三個任務:
任務一: 請使用者設定施力(FA) 與推車質量(MA) 使得推車以2公尺/秒2 的加速度前進
任務二: 請設定三組施力(F)與物體質量(M)，使得物體移動的加速度為2.5公尺/秒2，完成設定後請按"送出答案"鈕確認答案，並觀察物體質量-施力作圖。
任務三: 當固定施力為F=10 牛頓時，請輸入三組物體質量(M)與其對應加速度a，完成設定後請按"送出答案"鈕確認答案，並觀察家速度a-物體質量作圖。

感謝台中市西苑高中洪菁穗老師與新竹縣康乃薾國民中小學簡子惠老師參與模擬設計討論

v.abstract: 此程式模擬一不受外力的作用的靜止的船上載著馬力歐，當馬力歐開始以等速 Va 向船緣移動時，馬力歐與船的運動。
v.desc:
此程式模擬一不受外力的作用的靜止的船上載著馬力歐，假設船與水面間無摩擦力，當馬力歐開始以等速 Va 向船緣移動時，馬力歐與船的運動。 假設一開始馬力歐的質點位置x=0，馬力歐重 Ma 公斤，船身重Mb公斤，船身全長為 2000 公分(船的質點位置 x=1000)。當馬力歐移動至船緣時模擬會停止。模擬中可調控馬力歐質量(Ma)，馬力歐的移動速度(Va)，與船的質量(Mb)，你能從調控參數去觀察兩者運動的變化與系統質心的關係(位置與速度)，或是歸納出動量守恆的觀念嗎? 還有當馬力歐走到船邊時的位移量dx與哪些參數相關呢?
可調參數:
Ma: 馬力歐質量 (公斤)
Va: 馬力歐的移動速度(公分/秒)
Mb: 船的質量 (公斤)
模擬操作: 設定好參數 (Ma, Va, Mb) 後按Play 執行模擬，按Reset 結束模擬。
顯示說明:
橘色圓點: 馬力歐每間個一秒的質點位置
黑色圓點: 船每間隔一秒的質點位置
桃紅色圓點: 系統質心位置
藍色箭頭: 馬力歐的移動速度
棕色箭頭: 船的移動速度
紫色線段: 馬力歐走到船邊時距離起點的位移
數據欄:
t: 時間
Ma: 馬力歐質量 (公斤)
Xa: 馬力歐的質點位置 (公分)
Va: 馬力歐的速度 (公分/秒)
Mb: 船的質量 (公斤)
Xb: 船的質點位置 (公分)
Vb: 船的速度 (公分/秒)
Xc: 系統的質心位置 (公分)
Vc: 系統的質心速度 (公分/秒)
D: 馬力歐走到船邊時距離起點的位移

v.abstract: 此程式模擬打樁的重錘受重力由靜止落下後擊中地上的樁子，將樁子槌入地面下的運動過程
v.desc:
此程式模擬打樁的重槌受重力由靜止落下後擊中地上的樁子，將樁子槌入地面下的運動過程。使用這可以設定重錘的高度(H)與重錘的質量(M)，執行模擬後觀察重錘的運動與樁子被打入地面的深度，以探究運動過程中功與能的變化；使用者也可以設定不同的任務模式，來設定參數挑戰並完成指定任務。
任務模式:
"無": 無指定任務，可任意設定參數執行模擬，並觀察運動過程與結果
"樁子完全打入土裡": 請設定適當參數，讓重錘擊中樁子後，樁子完全打入土裡
"樁子不可以敲到石頭": 請設定適當參數，讓重錘擊中樁子後，樁子最接近石頭卻沒有敲到石頭
可調參數:
H: 重錘的高度
M: 重錘的質量

v.abstract: 此程式模擬光線射入平面鏡後反射的光路
v.desc:
此程式模擬光線射入平面鏡後反射的光路。模擬的情境設定是小紅帽去探視生病的外婆，聽說近來森林中的大野狼正四處做壞，來到外婆門外發現屋內是一片漆黑，小紅帽無法看清楚屋內的狀況。模擬畫面中有一道雷射光與三面平面鏡，你可以控制雷射光射出的角度與三面平面鏡擺設的角度，要請你幫忙讓雷射光射出後經過三面平面鏡的反射，將光線導入到模擬畫面右方的星星處，當光線擊中星星後屋內就會全亮，能讓小紅帽看清楚屋裡的狀況。你能幫忙完成任務，說出屋內有哪人和他們所在的位置嗎? 此外，在模擬的左下角有可以拖動的量角器，在完成任務後請你量測光線入射鏡子時的入射角與反射後光線的反射角，探究兩個角度間有甚麼關係呢?
模擬操作:
(1) 用滑數點選畫面中想調整角度的物件(雷射或平面鏡)
(2) 調整模擬左上變數拉桿"角度"的數值來設定物件的角度
(3) 調整雷射光與三面平面鏡的角度將光線導入到模擬畫面右方的星星處完成任務
(4) 使用滑鼠點選量角器並拖曳至享量測角度的面鏡上，調整模擬左上變數拉桿"角度"的數值來設定量角器的角度智與平面鏡平行，並量測光的入射角與與反射角
(5) 按"重置"鈕可以重置模擬

感謝宜蘭縣宜蘭國中吳宛如老師參與設計模擬與討論

v.abstract: 此程式模擬一以等速度行駛的車輛，行駛中踩剎車至車輛停止的過程。任務是控制車輛停止在紅色停止線上。
v.ml_infoTitle: 等速與等加速度運動-來得急剎車嗎-1
v.desc:
等速與等加速度運動-來得急剎車嗎 此程式模擬一以等速度行駛的車輛，行駛中踩剎車至車輛停止的過程。一輛貨車子以等速度V (公尺/秒)行駛，於x=0處看見前方100公尺處有ㄧ隻小貓，駕駛可於距離小貓d公尺處踩剎車，踩剎車後車輛以 a (公尺/秒^2)的等減速度減速然後停止。 (1) 可控制行車速度V，等減速度a，與踩剎車處d觀察運動的過程 (2) 活動設計駕駛操控車輛行車速度V與踩剎車的位置，控制車輛停止在紅色停止線上。 備註：當汽車完全停止時的位置若是距離停止線1.5公尺內則為任務成功，反之任務失敗。
可調參數:
V: 汽車速度 (公尺/秒)
a: 汽車等減速度 (公尺/秒2 )
d: 距離小貓d公尺處踩剎車 (公尺)
模擬操作:
(1) 設定汽車速度V，等減速度a 與踩剎車處d 後按Play執行模擬
(2) 停止模擬按Reset，可重新設定參數執行新模擬
顯示說明:
(1) 綠色小點表示每間隔一秒汽車的軌跡
(2) 藍色箭頭是汽車的速度
(3) 紫色箭頭是踩剎車處
(4) 數據欄:
      t: 時間(秒)
      x: 汽車的位置/位移 (公尺)
      V: 汽車的速度 (公尺/秒)
      a: 汽車的等減速度 (公尺/秒2)
      d: 距離小貓d公尺處踩剎車
      dx: 汽車停止時離停止線的距離

v.abstract: 此程式模擬山崖上有隻質量為 Ma的生氣鳥，以等速度 Vxa向右移動碰撞ㄧ顆質量為 Mb彩蛋的運動過程，任務是使彩蛋落地時擊中豬頭。
v.desc:
此程式模擬完全彈性碰撞與水平拋射的運動過程。 位於180公尺高的山崖上有隻質量為 Ma(公斤) 的生氣鳥，以等速度 Vxa(公尺/秒) 向右 (+X方向)移動，在山崖邊有ㄧ顆質量為 Mb(公斤)彩蛋。當生氣鳥碰撞到彩蛋時為完全彈性碰撞，彩蛋墬落至山崖下 (重力加速度 g=10 公尺/秒^2)。於地面距離山崖邊180公尺處有ㄧ顆豬頭。請你調控適當參數值(Vax，Ma，Mb) 使得彩蛋落地時恰巧擊中豬頭。
可調參數:
Vxa: 生氣鳥速度 (公尺/秒)
Ma: 生氣鳥質量 (公斤)
Mb: 彩蛋質量 (公斤)
模擬操作: 設定好可調參數後按 Play 執行模擬，停止模擬請按Reset。
數據欄:
Ma: 生氣鳥質量 (公斤)
Vxa: 生氣鳥水平速度 (公尺/秒)
Mb: 彩蛋質量 (公斤)
Vxb: 彩蛋水平速度 (X方向，公尺/秒)
Vyb: 彩蛋垂直速度 (Y方向，公尺/秒)
教育雲上的完全彈性碰撞教學影片:https://video.cloud.edu.tw/video/co_video_content.php?p=393739
此模擬在因材網有更完整的資源(因材網首頁→登入→課程總覽→互動式教學→自然)，包含學習單、課程引導影片、及素養題測驗。
https://adl.edu.tw/HomePage/home/

This simulation demonstrates the kinetic motions of N=21 uncoupled pendulums. The frequency difference (df) between nearby pendulums is fixed so that the lengths of the pendulums are monotonically increasing. In this simulation, the frequency of the slowest pendulum (with the longest length) is f (1/s) . The frequency of the fastest pendulum (with the shortest length) is ff (1/s). The frequency difference between the nearby pendulums is df=(ff-f)/(N-1). Students can observe the dynamics of N=21 pendulums firstly. Thereafter, adjust the number of the pendulum N from 2 to more to learn how and why the pendulums could form the wave-like motions.        

Note: 
(a) t is the real time; CT is the time when all pendulums are swing to the same phase (line-up)
(b) when N<9, the numbers next to pendulums are their corresponding length (cm).
(c) g=980 cm/s^2

Variables:
N: number of pendulums
f: the frequency of the slowest pendulum (1/s)
ff: the frequency of the fastest pendulum (1/s)

To run the simulation:

Press "Play" after variables are set upon your request. Press "Reset" to stop the simulation.

data sheet:
t: time (s)
N: number of pendulums
f: the frequency of the slowest pendulum (1/s)
ff: the frequency of the fastest pendulum (1/s)


reference: : 師大物理問題討論區 黃福坤教授
http://www.phy.ntnu.edu.tw/demolab/phpBB/viewtopic.php?topic=21343

v.abstract: 此程式模擬空間中有兩個電荷時所形成的電場分布與電力線。
v.desc:
此程式模擬空間中兩個電荷所形成的電場分布與電力線。模擬中使用者可以調變兩電荷的電性與電荷量(q1,q2)觀察空間中靜電場分佈(灰色箭頭)，以滑鼠拖動畫面左下方的電場偵測器(綠色方框)以顯示黃色圓點處的電場強度，或勾選方框以顯示電力線，電力線以動態畫出，由正電荷端畫出，中於負電荷端。
可調參數:
q1: 電荷1的電性與帶電量
q2: 電荷2的電性與帶電量
勾選方框: 勾選顯示/隱藏電力線

模擬參考: 師大物理黃福坤教授物理問題討論區 http://www.phy.ntnu.edu.tw/demolab/phpBB/viewtopic.php?topic=17954

v.abstract: 此程式模擬一單擺運動。
v.desc:
此程式模擬一單擺運動。模擬中有一個質量為 m(公克) 的圓球擺錘，擺線的長度為 L(公分)，擺角為 c(度)，擺線與固定軸間的摩擦係數為 r。使用者可選擇實驗地點，調整上述參數，觀察擺的周期與這些參數間的關係。
可調參數:
地點: 地球(g=980 公分/秒平方)；月球(g=163.3 公分/秒平方)
c: 擺角(度)
L: 擺長(公分)
m: 擺錘質量(公克)
r: 擺線與固定軸間的摩擦係數
單選方框:
擺錘速度: 勾選顯示擺錘速度(紅色箭頭)

執行模擬:
(1) 設定可調參數後按 Play 執行模擬
      簡諧運動 與 力學能 圖表同步顯示 擺角/角速度，力學能/位能/動能 隨時間變化的作圖。
(2) 按 Pause 可暫停模擬，搭配模擬畫面中的碼錶，使用者可紀錄固定擺動次數的時間來計算擺的周期
(3) 結束模擬請按 Reset，可重新設定參數後按 Play 執行下一次模擬。

在十六世紀前計時器多以水力或重錘轉動齒輪的機械式時鐘，其體積龐大且精準度不佳，通常只能到準確到數十分鐘。伽利略因觀察到比薩教堂裡因風搖晃的吊燈的擺動，設計了單擺實驗，藉由改變擺的長度，擺垂重量等因子歸納出擺的擺動周期與這幾個因子間的關係。單擺的往復擺動是最早觀察到物理的簡諧運動的實例，單擺穩定的周期性提供了精準的計時方式，伽利略於晚年被囚禁時(西元1637年)與兒子共同設計了以單擺為調節驅力的擺鐘，可惜那時他年事已高並來不及將它完成，而是於西元1656年，荷蘭科學家海更斯Christiaan Huygens 設計完成第一個以秒計時的擺鐘。爾後，製作擺鐘的技術不斷進步，西元1720後，英國鐘表匠哈里森 John Harrison 製作的擺鐘一個月的時間誤差才1秒，且至今仍正常擺動計時。哈里森更利用彈簧設計可在船上使用的航海時鐘，準確的計時讓航海家得以計算出船隻航行時所處的經度，避免船難讓長距離的海上航行更安全，進而將世界推入大航海時代與其後的國際貿易。而於科學上，精準的計時是推動科學實驗的基石，描述物體運動，觀察天體的運行都需要準確的計時才得以讓科學家們歸納出物理定律。
